para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: In accordance with the provisions of State Tax-Property Article § 9-202, there is hereby established a tax credit from Baltimore City real property taxes levied on any improvement:
located on the site of cemetery property that is exempt under State Tax-Property Article § 7-201,
if the improvement is used as a dwelling by an employee of the owner of the exempt property.
The owner must file an application for this tax credit with the Director of Finance annually, on or before September 1 of the taxable year for which the credit is sought.
The application for the tax credit shall contain information that the Director of Finance considers necessary for determining the eligibility of the applicant.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance may adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this section.

para.heading: Penalties for false statement.
para.text: Any applicant who makes a false statement for the purpose of obtaining a tax credit under this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 90 days or both fine and imprisonment.

para.heading: "Vacant dwelling" defined.
para.text: In this section, "vacant dwelling" means residential real property that:
contains no more than 4 dwelling units; and
either:
has been cited as vacant and abandoned on a housing or building violation notice for 1 year; or
has been owned by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City for 1 year and is in need of substantial repair to comply with applicable City codes.

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: In accordance with the provisions of State Tax-Property Article § 9-304(c) , there is hereby granted a tax credit against the Baltimore City real property tax imposed on a vacant dwelling owned and occupied as the principle residence by a qualifying owner.

para.heading: Qualifications.
para.text: Owners of vacant dwellings may qualify for the tax credit authorized by this section by:
substantially rehabilitating the vacant dwelling in compliance with the code and laws applied to dwellings;
occupying the dwelling after rehabilitation as their principal residence; and
satisfying other requirements as may be provided in a Resolution of the Board of Estimates.

para.heading: Amount of credit.
para.text: A property tax credit granted under this section may not exceed the amount of City property tax imposed on the increased value of the residential real property that is due to the improvements made to the property immediately before the occupancy permit was issued, multiplied by:
100% for the 1st taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
80% for the 2nd taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
60% for the 3rd taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
40% for the 4th taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
20% for the 5th taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit; and
0% for each taxable year thereafter.
The owner shall file an application for this tax credit with the Director of Finance annually, on or before September 1 of the taxable year for which the credit is sought.
The application for the tax credit shall contain information that the Board of Estimates considers necessary for determining the eligibility of the applicant.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Board of Estimates may adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this section.

para.heading: Penalties for false statement.
para.text: Any applicant who, for the purpose of obtaining a tax credit under the provisions of this section, makes a false statement on the application shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than $500.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: In this section, "newly constructed dwelling" and "owner"have the meanings stated in State Tax-Property Article § 9-304(d).

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: There is established a property tax credit, as authorized in State Tax-Property Article § 9-304(d), against the property tax imposed on newly constructed dwellings that are owned by qualifying owners.

para.heading: Qualifications.
para.text: The owner of a newly constructed dwelling may qualify for the tax credit authorized by this section by:
purchasing a newly constructed dwelling;
occupying that dwelling as his or her principal residence;
filing an application for the credit either:
within 90 days after settling on the purchase of the dwelling; or
within 90 days after the owner first receives an assessment on the building;
for each taxable year for which the credit is sought, filing a state income tax return as a resident of Baltimore City; and
satisfying all other conditions imposed by the regulations of the Director of Finance.

para.heading: Amount of credit.
para.text: A property tax credit granted under this section may not exceed the amount of property tax imposed on the real property, less the amount on any other credit applicable in that year, multiplied by:
50% for the 1st taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
40% for the 2nd taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
30% for the 3rd taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
20% for the 4th taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
10% for the 5th taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit; and
0% for each taxable year thereafter.

Subject to the approval of the Board of Estimates, and subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance shall adopt regulations to carry out the provisions of this section.
These regulations:
shall include procedures necessary and appropriate for the submission of an application for and the granting of a property tax credit under this section; and
may include procedures for granting partial credits for eligibility for less than a full taxable year.

para.heading: Reporting credits.
para.text: The estimated amount of all tax credits received by owners under this section in any fiscal year:
shall be reported by the Director of Finance of Baltimore City as a "tax expenditure" for that fiscal year; and
shall be included in the publication of the City's budget for any subsequent fiscal year with the estimated or actual City property tax revenue for the applicable fiscal year.
The Director of Finance shall develop by January 1, 1996, a method, which shall be approved by the Board of Estimates, for analysis of the public costs and benefits of the tax credits.
The method will include development of baseline data to include new residential construction, new housing tenure, and net migration trends in the City.

Measurement of the public costs and benefits of the tax credit will be made against baseline data and will include credit and administrative costs and estimates of benefits from property, income, and transfer tax revenues.

para.heading: Annual report of analysis.
para.text: The Director of Finance shall report annually to the Board of Estimates and to the Mayor and City Council the results and findings of that analysis, including the steps taken and proposed to be taken to promote and otherwise further the use of the tax credit program.
After June 30, 2019, additional owners of newly constructed dwellings may not be granted a credit under this section.

This subsection does not apply to an owner's continuing receipt of a credit as allowed in subsection (d) with respect to a property for which a tax credit under this section was received for a taxable year ending on or before June 30, 2019.

para.heading: Definitions.
para.text: The definitions for "dwelling" and "homeowner" contained in State Tax-Property Article § 9-304(e) are incorporated into this section by this reference.

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: There is established a property tax credit, as authorized in State Tax-Property Article § 9-304(e), against the property tax imposed on the increased value of the dwelling that is due to improvements made to the property that is owned by qualifying owners.
The tax credit granted under the provisions of this section shall be applied against the property tax on a dwelling that:
is owned by a homeowner;
has been substantially improved since the last reassessment; and
is reassessed at a higher value.
The property tax credit may not apply to the value of the improvements to the dwelling that exceed $100,000.

To receive the tax credit under this section, the homeowner shall have the burden of showing that the increase in assessment is due to the value of the improvements to the dwelling that were made since the last assessment of the dwelling.
To continue eligibility for a tax credit under this section, a dwelling must remain in compliance with the City Property Maintenance Code.

If a dwelling owned by a person who has received a tax credit under this section is found to be in violation of the City Property Maintenance Code, the property owner is not eligible for any further tax credit under this section until the dwelling is determined again to be in compliance with that Code.
A dwelling that is again brought into compliance is eligible for a tax credit at the rate it would have been eligible before the violation of the Property Maintenance Code.

In addition to compliance with the Property Maintenance Code, the homeowner shall comply with all other parts of the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article, including their permit requirements for improvements.

para.heading: Amount of credit.
para.text: The tax credit provided under this section shall equal the amount of property tax imposed on the increased value of the dwelling that is due to the improvements made to the property, multiplied by:
100% for the 1st taxable year following the 1st reassessment after the improvements are made;
80% for the 2nd taxable year following the 1st reassessment after the improvements are made;
60% for the 3rd taxable year following the 1st reassessment after the improvements are made;
40% for the 4th taxable year following the 1st reassessment after the improvements are made;
20% for the 5th taxable year following the 1st reassessment after the improvements are made; and
0% for each taxable year thereafter.

para.heading: Transfers of property.
para.text: If a dwelling that is eligible for a tax credit under this section is transferred, the grantee is eligible for the balance of the property tax credits under this section in the same manner and under the same conditions as the grantor of the property.

para.heading: Rules and regulations; administration.
para.text: The Director of Finance may:
subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations necessary to implement the provisions of this section;
settle disputed claims that may arise in connection with the credit authorized by this section; and
delegate powers, duties, or functions in connection with the administration of the credit authorized by this section to the City Collector or any other employee of the City.

section.heading: Neighborhood preservation and stabilization demonstration project.

para.heading: Definition.
para.text: "Project Area" means the neighborhood preservation and stabilization demonstration project area designated by the Mayor in accordance with State Tax-Property Article § 9-326 for participation in a demonstration project for neighborhood preservation and stabilization.

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: In accordance with § 9-326 of the State Tax-Property Article, a property tax credit is established against the property tax imposed on owner-occupied residential real property that is purchased on or after July 1, 1996, and on or before June 30, 2001, in the area designated as the neighborhood preservation and stabilization demonstration project area.

para.heading: Qualifications.
para.text: The tax credit granted under this section applies only if, for the 12-month period immediately prior to purchasing the property, the applicant's principal residence was neither in the project area nor in the corresponding area of Baltimore County, unless the applicant was not an owner of the property that was the applicant's principal residence.

para.heading: Application deadline.
para.text: To qualify for a tax credit under this section, an individual must apply for the credit:
within 6 months after title to the property was transferred to the individual; or
for property purchased before June 1, 1999, on or before December 1, 1999.

para.heading: Amount of credit.
para.text: The property tax credit shall equal:
40% of the property tax for each of the first 5 taxable years after the purchase of the real property;
35% of the property tax for the 6th taxable year after the purchase of the real property;
30% of the property tax for the 7th taxable year after the purchase of the real property;
25% of the property tax for the 8th taxable year after the purchase of the real property;
20% of the property tax for the 9th taxable year after the purchase of the real property;
15% of the property tax for the 10th taxable year after the purchase of the real property; and
0% of the property tax for each subsequent taxable year.

para.heading: When credit first applies.
para.text: The property tax credit shall first apply to the taxable year beginning after the date of the purchase of the eligible real property.

para.heading: Director to provide statement of qualification.
para.text: On an annual basis, the Director of Finance shall provide to each individual qualifying for the tax credit under this section a statement certifying qualification for the tax credit and the amount of the tax credit being granted. The statement may be provided on or with the annual property tax bill or in another manner chosen by the Director of Finance.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance may adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this section.

para.heading: Penalties for false statement.
para.text: Any person who makes a false statement for the purpose of obtaining a tax credit under this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 6 months, or both.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following words have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: CHAP.
para.text: "CHAP" means the Commission for Historical and Architectural Preservation or the Commission's designee.

para.heading: Eligible improvements.
para.text: "Eligible improvements" means significant improvements to an historic property that have been approved by CHAP as meeting local preservation standards.

para.heading: Historic property.
para.text: "Historic property" means a property:
individually listed on the National Register of Historic Places;
individually listed on the City Landmark List;
located within a National Register Historic or Landmark District and certified by CHAP as contributing to the historic significance of that district;
located within a City Historical and Architectural Preservation District and certified by CHAP as contributing to the historic significance of that district; or
included within the boundaries of a certified heritage area.

para.heading: Significant improvements.
para.text: "Significant improvements" means improvements, restoration, or rehabilitation for which the total documented construction cost equals or exceeds 25% of a property's full cash value before commencement of the improvements, restoration, or rehabilitation.

para.heading: Program goal.
para.text: The goal of this program is to help preserve and revitalize Baltimore's neighborhoods by encouraging home and business owners to make special efforts to restore or rehabilitate historic buildings.

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: In accordance with State Tax-Property Article § 9-204.1, a 10-year tax credit is granted against the City real property tax attributable to eligible improvements of historic properties.

para.heading: CHAP approval required.
para.text: The tax credit granted by this section applies only to eligible improvements that, before the improvements are begun, have been preliminarily approved by CHAP as meeting local historic preservation standards.

para.heading: Calculation adjustments.
para.text: The calculations specified in paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection are subject to:
the reduction required by paragraph (5) of this subsection; and
the limitations imposed by subsections (f) and (f-2) of this section.
For credits initially granted under this section before October 1, 2014, and for the duration of the credit, the credit is equal to the difference between:
the real property tax on the most recent full cash value of the property before the commencement of eligible improvements; and
the real property tax on the most recent full cash value of the property after completion of the eligible improvements.

For purposes of this calculation, the full cash value of the property is the full cash value before phase in, as determined by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation through the assessment procedures established under Tax-Property Article, Title 8, of the Maryland Code.

para.heading: Credits initially granted on or after October 1, 2014.

para.text: For credits initially granted under this section on or after October 1, 2014, and for the duration of the credit, the credit is equal to the difference between:
the real property tax on the full cash value of the property before the commencement of eligible improvements; and
the real property tax on the full cash value of the property after completion of the eligible improvements.

For purposes of this calculation, the full cash value of the property shall be determined by an appraisal of the property before commencement and after completion of eligible improvements by a professional appraiser selected by the City and licensed under Business Occupations and Professions Article, Title 16, Subtitle 3, of the Maryland Code.

Notwithstanding paragraph (3) of this subsection, if a property received preliminary approval under subsection (d) of this section before October 1, 2014, the credit shall be calculated in accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection.
The credit calculated under this subsection shall be reduced by the amount of the credit, if any, for which the property is eligible under the Maryland Enterprise Zone Tax Credit Program.

para.heading: Amount of credit – Limitation on projects costing more than $5 million.
para.text: For development projects exceeding $5 million in documented construction costs, the tax credit is limited to the following percentages of the amount computed under subsection (e) of this section:

para.heading: Special requirements for projects costing more than $3.5 million.

para.text: This subsection applies only to development projects exceeding $3.5 million in documented construction costs,
For a project subject to this subsection to be eligible for any tax credit under this section:
the developer must:
submit all documents requested by the Finance Director; and

submit documentation reviewed by the developer with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation to support a preliminary estimate of value for tax purposes based on construction costs and projected income; and
either:
the existing building in question must have been at least 75% vacant for at least 3 years;

the project is a high-performance market-rate rental housing project, as these terms are defined in § 10-18 (a)(2) {"Definitions: High-performance"} and (a)(3) {"Definitions: Market-rate rental housing project"} of this subtitle; or
the developer must otherwise demonstrate to the Finance Director that the credit is necessary in order for the project to proceed.

When a project subject to this subsection applies for the credit, the developer must submit a statement of projected economic impact and public benefits for the project. 3 years from the date an application is accepted, the developer must submit statements of actual economic impact and public benefits for the project. Public benefit measures include neighborhood revitalization impact, job creation, tax generation, and minority business development.

If a project subject to this subsection is located in a Maryland Enterprise Zone, the credit under this section may be taken only for those parts of the property that have been rejected as ineligible for the enterprise zone tax credit.

para.heading: Limitation on amount of credit applied.
para.text: No part of any credit calculated under this section may be applied in any tax year:

to reduce the property's tax liability for that tax year, after application of any other applicable credit, to less than the tax liability to which the property was subject, after application of any other applicable tax credit, before commencement of the eligible improvements; or

in any case in which the property's tax liability for that tax year, after application of any other applicable credit, is less than the tax liability to which the property was subject, after application of any other applicable tax credit, before commencement of the eligible improvements.

para.heading: Additional requirements.
para.text: A credit under this section:
is subject to eligibility requirements no less stringent than those applicable to credits authorized under Tax-Property Article § 9-204, of the Maryland Code;

is limited to a period of 10 consecutive tax years (or portion of a tax year), beginning with the first billing period that occurs after CHAP and the Finance Director have issued their final approvals;
is fully transferrable to a new owner for the remaining life of the credit; and
terminates if the property is converted so as to no longer meet established historic preservation standards.

para.heading: Continuing eligibility.
para.text: During the credit period, the property owner shall:
maintain the major historic features of the property;
ensure that the property for which the credit was granted is in full compliance with the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article; and
submit all statements required by subsection (f-1)(3) of this section.

para.heading: No tax subsidy duplication allowed.
para.text: Except for the Maryland State Enterprise Zone Tax Credit Program, the credit authorized by this section does not apply to any property for which any other tax subsidy from the City, whether in the form of a tax credit, payment in lieu of taxes, or otherwise, is being received or has been applied for.
A property owner seeking this credit shall:
file an application with CHAP; and
pay the application fee set by the Board of Estimates.
The application shall contain the information, including identification of major historic features, that CHAP considers necessary for determining the eligibility of the applicant.

para.heading: Administration.
para.text: The Finance Director, after consultation with the Director of Planning, may:
subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to carry out this section;
settle any disputed claims that may arise in connection with the credit authorized by this section; and
delegate his or her powers and duties to administer this section to any employee or agency of the City.
CHAP, in coordination with the Department of Finance, shall establish review procedures for the credit program established by this section.
The Department of Finance shall analyze the data submitted under subsection (f)(3) of this section.

para.heading: Termination of program.
para.text: Applications for a credit under this section may not be accepted after August 28, 2024.

para.heading: Criminal penalties.
para.text: Any person who knowingly makes a false statement on or in connection with an application for a tax credit under this section or in connection with any report or statement supporting a property's continued eligibility for a tax credit granted under this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.text: In this section, the following words have the meanings indicated.

"Market-rate rental housing project" means a multifamily dwelling containing 5 or more units in which none of the units are subject to government restrictions on the amount of rent charged or the income level of the tenant.
"Newly constructed" means:
newly erected on a vacant lot;
converted from non-residential use, provided the conversion/ construction costs exceed $60,000 per unit; or

substantially rehabilitated, provided the structure was a dwelling identified by the Commissioner of Housing, through issuance of a "vacant house notice" or otherwise, as having been vacant and unfit for human habitation for a period of at least 1 year prior to issuance of a construction permit for the project, and provided the rehabilitation/construction costs exceed $60,000 per unit;
for which, in each case, a first occupancy permit following construction is issued after January 1, 1996.

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: In accordance with the provisions of State Tax-Property Article § 9-304(f), there is established a tax credit against the Baltimore City real property tax imposed on newly constructed market-rate rental housing projects.

para.heading: Amount of credit.
para.text: The amount of a property tax credit granted under this section shall be the amount of City real property tax imposed on a market-rate rental housing project, less the amount of any other credit applicable in that year, multiplied by:
50% for the 1st taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
40% for the 2nd taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
30% for the 3rd taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
20% for the 4th taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
10% for the 5th taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit; and
0% for each taxable year thereafter.

para.heading: When credit first applies.
para.text: A newly constructed market-rate rental housing project qualifies for a tax credit under this section when an occupancy permit is first issued for the project following construction.

para.heading: Deadline for qualification.
para.text: A newly constructed market-rate rental housing project with an occupancy permit issued after June 30, 2001 shall not qualify for a tax credit under this section.

The owner of a newly constructed market-rate rental housing project shall file an application for a tax credit under this section with the Director of Finance on or before September 1 of the 1st taxable year in which the property qualifies and shall file an application annually thereafter for each year in which the credit is sought.
The application shall contain all information that the Director of Finance considers necessary for determining the eligibility of the applicant.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.

para.text: In this section, the following words have the meanings indicated.
"Brownfields Incentive Fund" means the Brownfields Revitalization Incentive Fund established under Article 83A, § 3-904 of the Maryland Code.
"Brownfields Incentive Program" means the Brownfields Revitalization Incentive Program established under Article 83A, Title 3, Subtitle 9 of the Maryland Code.
"Brownfields site" means a qualified Brownfields site, as defined in Article 83A, § 3-901(d) of the Maryland Code.

"Increased property tax liability" means the remaining property tax liability, after first applying all other property tax credits applicable to the site, attributable to the increase in the assessment of a Brownfields site, including improvements added to the site within the tax-credit period provided for in this section, over the assessment of the Brownfields site before its voluntary cleanup.

para.heading: Election to participate in Program.
para.text: Pursuant to § 9-229 of the State Tax-Property Article, the City of Baltimore elects to participate in the Brownfields Incentive Program and to provide the tax credits authorized by this section.

para.heading: Tax-credit period.
para.text: The credit granted by this section applies in each of the taxable years immediately following the 1st revaluation of the Brownfields site after completion of a voluntary cleanup or corrective action plan, for a total of:
5 taxable years; or
if the site is in a designated State Enterprise Zone, 10 taxable years.

para.heading: Basic 50% credit.
para.text: The amount of the tax credit is 50% of the Brownfields site's increased property tax liability.

para.heading: Additional 20% in credits for certain sites.
para.text: An additional credit of 20% of a Brownfields site's increased property tax liability shall be granted if the aggregate cost of the site's purchase and the voluntary cleanup or corrective action plan efforts equals or exceeds $250,000.

para.heading: Contribution to Incentive Fund.
para.text: For each year of the tax-credit period specified in subsection (c) of this section, the City shall contribute to the Brownfields Incentive Fund an amount equal to 30% of a Brownfields site's increased property tax liability.

para.heading: Credits transferability.
para.text: The credits provided for in subsections (d) and (e) of this section may be transferred to a purchaser of the property for the remaining term of the credit.

para.heading: Termination of credit.
para.text: The tax credit granted under this section terminates if:
the recipient of the credit withdraws from the voluntary cleanup program under § 7-512(a) or (b) of the Environment Article;
the Department of the Environment withdraws approval of a response action plan or a certificate of completion under § 7-512(e) and (f) of the Environment Article; or
the recipient of the credit otherwise ceases to qualify for the credit under this section or the rules and regulations adopted under this section.
An application for a tax credit under this section must be filed in the 1st taxable year in which the property qualifies.
The application must be made on the form and contain the information that the Director of Finance specifies.
Before a credit may be granted, the applicant must provide satisfactory evidence of:
completion of a voluntary cleanup or corrective action plan approved by the State Department of the Environment; and
for the additional credit provided under subsection (e) of this section, the cost of the site's purchase and of the voluntary cleanup or corrective action plan.

para.heading: Administration.
para.text: The Director of Finance may:
subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this section;
settle any disputed claims arising in connection with the credit authorized by this section; and
delegate his or her powers and duties to administer this section to any employee or agency of the City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Eligible area.
para.text: "Eligible area" means any area that is eligible for designation as an eligible neighborhood under Article 83B, §§ 4-201 through 4-208 of the Maryland Code.

para.heading: Qualifying renovations.
para.text: "Qualifying renovations" means infrastructure renovations to accommodate advanced computer and telecommunications systems, including the installation of fiber-optic cable, emergency electrical capacity, emergency back-up power, fiber-optic risers, internal/external network cabling, information outlets, and other specialized equipment.

para.heading: State-of-the-art communications and utility standards.
para.text: "State-of-the-art communications and utility standards" means the communication and utility standards published by the Electrical Industry Association and the Telecommunications Industry Association as EIA/TIA Standard 568, generally referred to as "Class 5" Installations.

para.heading: Tax credit authorized.
para.text: A real property tax credit is granted against the City property tax imposed on a commercial (including commercial-residential) building:
that is in an eligible area; and
to which qualifying renovations have been made to meet state-of-the-art communications and utility standards.

para.heading: Amount of credit.
para.text: The tax credit granted under this section for any 1 taxable year shall equal 7.5% of the cost of qualifying renovations, subject to a maximum cumulative credit of $750,000 for the 10-year credit period. The credit shall be applied only to that part of the taxes due that exceed the tax calculated on the fully phased-in pre-improvement value of the property.
A tax credit may be granted under this section only for 10 years or until the maximum credit amount of $750,000 is reached, whichever is first.
The 10-year credit period begins after:
the qualifying renovations have been completed;
the Building Official gives final approval to the project; and
the State Department of Assessments and Taxation completes an assessment review.
The credit will be first applied to the tax bill generated after the State Department of Assessments and Taxation has issued a revised assessment notice on a part- or full-year basis.

para.heading: No tax subsidy duplication allowed.
para.text: The credit authorized by this section does not apply to any property for which any other tax subsidy from the City, whether in the form of a tax credit, payment in lieu of taxes, or otherwise, is being received or has been applied for.

The person responsible for paying property taxes should file an initial application for the credit concurrently with the application for building permits for the renovation work. In no event, however, may any application for a credit be accepted after a building permit is issued. The application shall estimate the costs of the proposed qualifying renovations, separately from all other costs.

Before renovations begin, the applicant must file renovation plans with the City Building Official and obtain preliminary approval that the plans meet state-of-the-art communication and utility standards.
During construction and on completion of the renovations, the applicant must obtain certification from the Building Official that the renovations conform to the approved plans.
On completion of the renovations, the applicant must provide documented evidence of the costs of the qualifying renovations.

para.heading: Continuing eligibility requirements.
para.text: The use of the credit in any year is conditioned on the taxpayer's:
maintaining the property in compliance with all City housing, building, health, fire, and other applicable City Code requirements; and
remaining current on all payments due to the City.
The Director of Finance may:
subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to carry out this section;
settle disputed claims that may arise in connection with the credit authorized by this section; and
delegate powers, duties, or functions in connection with the administration of this credit to the City Collector or any other City employee.

The Director of Finance shall report the estimated cost of all tax credits granted under this section in any fiscal year as a tax expenditure for that fiscal year and shall include that cost in the Ordinance of Estimates for that fiscal year.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Arts and entertainment district.
para.text: "Arts and entertainment district" has the meaning stated in State Economic Development Article, § 4-701.

para.heading: Arts and entertainment enterprise.
para.text: "Arts and entertainment enterprise" has the meaning stated in State Economic Development Article, § 4-701.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of Finance or designee.

para.heading: Eligible assessment.
para.text: "Eligible assessment" means the phased-in value, as applied by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation in the 1st, 2nd, or 3rd year in a 3-year cycle under State Tax-Property Article § 8-103, attributable to the qualifying renovations, as determined by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

para.heading: Qualifying renovations.
para.text: "Qualifying renovations" means renovations that are made:
to a manufacturing, commercial, or industrial building located in a State-designated arts and entertainment district; and
for use by a qualifying residing artist or an arts and entertainment enterprise.

para.heading: Qualifying residing artist.
para.text: "Qualifying residing artist" has the meaning stated in State Economic Development Article, § 4-701.
In accordance with State Tax-Property Article § 9-240, a real property tax credit is granted against the City property tax imposed on a manufacturing, commercial, or industrial building that:
is located in a State-designated arts and entertainment district; and
is wholly or partially renovated for use by a qualifying residing artist or an arts and entertainment enterprise.
The credit is prorated to reflect the proportion of the building used by a qualifying residing artist or an arts and entertainment enterprise.

para.heading: Term of credit.
para.text: A tax credit may be taken under this section for up to 10 years, as provided in subsection (d) of this section, subject to compliance with the continuing eligibility requirements of subsection (j) of this section.

Except for properties eligible for a Maryland Enterprise Zone Tax Credit, the amount of the credit granted under this section is the amount of property tax imposed on the eligible assessment of the property, multiplied by:
80% for the first 5 taxable years;
70% for the 6th taxable year;
60% for the 7th taxable year;
50% for the 8th taxable year;
40% for the 9th taxable year;
30% for the 10th taxable year; and
0% for each subsequent taxable year.

For properties eligible for a Maryland Enterprise Zone Tax Credit, the amount of the credit granted under this section is the amount of property tax imposed on the eligible assessment of the property, multiplied by:
20% for the first 5 taxable years;
30% for the 6th taxable year;
40% for the 7th taxable year;
50% for the 8th taxable year;
60% for the 9th taxable year;
70% for the 10th taxable year; and
0% for each subsequent taxable year.

para.heading: First year of credit.
para.text: The credit period begins after the first reassessment of the property by the State after the completion of qualifying renovations. The credit will first be applied to the tax bill generated after the State has issued a revised assessment notice, on a part- or full-year basis.

para.heading: Deadline for qualification.
para.text: Improvements made before July 1, 2002, do not qualify for a tax credit under this section.

para.heading: Credit transferability.
para.text: The tax credit granted by this section may be transferred to a purchaser of the property for the remaining term of the credit, subject to compliance with the continuing eligibility requirements of subsection (j) of this section.

para.heading: Application for credit.
para.text: The property owner must apply to the Director for a tax credit under this section within 90 days of receipt of an assessment notice reflecting the eligible assessment.

para.heading: No tax subsidy duplication allowed.
para.text: The credit granted under this section does not apply to any property for which any other tax subsidy from the City, other than a Maryland Enterprise Zone Tax Credit, is being received or has been applied for, whether in the form of a tax credit, payment in lieu of taxes, or otherwise.

para.heading: Continuing eligibility requirements.
para.text: The use of the credit in any year is conditioned on:
the property's compliance with all City housing, building, health, fire, and other applicable code requirements;
the taxpayer's remaining current on all payments due to the City;
the continued use of the property or eligible portion of the property by a qualifying residing artist or an arts and entertainment enterprise; and
the taxpayer's providing to the Director an annual certification of that continued use.

para.heading: Administration.
para.text: The Director may:
subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to implement the provisions of this section;
settle disputed claims that may arise in connection with the credit authorized by this section; and
delegate powers, duties, or functions in connection with the administration of the credit authorized by this section to any employee of the City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of Finance or designee.
"Dwelling" means real property that is occupied by not more than 2 families.
"Dwelling" includes the lot or curtilage and structures necessary to use the real property as a residence.
"Fallen hero" means, except as specified in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, any individual who dies:
as a result of or in the course of employment as a Baltimore City law enforcement officer; or
while in the active service of a Baltimore City fire, rescue, or emergency-medical service.
"Fallen hero" does not include any individual whose death was the result of his or her willful misconduct or his or her abuse of alcohol or drugs.

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: A real property tax credit is granted against the City property tax imposed on a dwelling if:
the dwelling is owned by the surviving spouse of a fallen hero;
the dwelling is the surviving spouse's legal residence;
the surviving spouse has not remarried; and
either:
the dwelling was owned by the fallen hero at the time of his or her death;
the fallen hero or the surviving spouse was domiciled in the State at the time the fallen hero died and the dwelling was acquired by the surviving spouse within 2 years of the death; or
the dwelling was acquired after the surviving spouse qualified for a credit under item (4)(i) or (ii) of this subsection for a former dwelling, to the extent of the previous credit.

para.heading: Term of credit.
para.text: The credit granted under this section continues from year to year, without further application by the surviving spouse.

para.heading: Amount of credit.
para.text: The amount of the credit granted under this section is 100% of the City property tax imposed on the dwelling.

para.heading: Administration.
para.text: The Director may:
subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to carry out this section;
settle disputed claims that arise in connection with the credit granted by this section; and
delegate powers, duties, or functions in connection with the administration of the credit to any employee of the City.

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: In accordance with State Tax-Property Article § 9-221, a Targeted Homeowner's Tax Credit is granted against the City property tax imposed on owner-occupied property that has qualified for the Homestead Tax Credit under State Property-Tax Article § 9-105.
The credit is calculated by multiplying credit rate by the assessed value of the improved portion of the property.
The credit shall be granted annually on the initial July tax bill. No partial year credits may be granted.
A homeowner is entitled to the credit granted under this section regardless of the amount of the Homestead Tax Credit to which the homeowner is entitled.

The rate of the credit for each tax year shall be set by the Board of Estimates on or before the date on which the Board of Estimates states the rate for the levy of full rate property taxes in that tax year.
A property tax credit granted under this section, when combined with other tax credits, may not exceed the amount of property tax imposed on the property.

Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance shall adopt rules and regulations necessary or appropriate to carry out the provisions of this section.

section.heading: High-performance market-rate rental housing – Targeted areas.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: High-performance.
para.text: "High-performance" means a high performance building as defined in State Tax-Property Article § 9-242.

para.heading: Market-rate rental housing project.
para.text: "Market-rate rental housing project" means a multi-family dwelling:
that contains 50 or more rental units; and

in which dwelling, except to the extent specifically required by City Code Article 13, Subtitle 2B {"Inclusionary Housing Requirements"}, none of the rental units are subject to governmental restrictions on the amount of rent charged or on the tenant's income level.

para.heading: Newly constructed or converted.
para.text: "Newly constructed or converted" means a high-performance market-rate rental housing project that:
was either:
newly constructed on a vacant lot, cleared site, or parking lot; or
converted from a non-residential use; and
for which:
the cost of the construction or conversion exceeds $60,000 per rental unit; and
a first occupancy permit following the construction or conversion is issued after January 1, 2013.

para.heading: Program goal.
para.text: The goal of this program is to help grow Baltimore's residential population in an environmentally sensitive manner, by encouraging the construction or conversion of new high-performance market-rate rental housing projects.

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: In accordance with State Tax-Property Article § 9-242, a High-Performance Market-Rate Rental Housing Tax Credit is granted against the City property tax imposed on eligible newly constructed or converted high-performance market-rate rental housing projects.
The amount of the credit shall equal a percentage, as specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, of 1 or another of the following:

if the property is still in the assessment cycle of the first assessment of the completed project following the issuance of an occupancy permit, the difference between the property tax liability that, but for the tax credit, is owed in the current year of the assessment cycle, and the total property tax liability on the assessed value of the property prior to the commencement of the project; or

if the property is no longer in the assessment cycle of the first assessment of the completed project following the issuance of an occupancy permit, the difference between the property tax liability that, but for the tax credit, was owed in the final year of that assessment cycle, and the total property tax liability on the assessed value of the property prior to the commencement of the project.
The credit is limited to the following percentages of the amount computed under paragraph (1) of this subsection:
In no event, however, may the tax credit granted under this section, alone or combined with the State Enterprise Zone Tax Credit, exceed the amount of the property tax imposed on the property.

para.heading: Qualified locations.
para.text: The property tax credit granted under this section applies only to eligible improvements that are located within the following areas:
Downtown Area, within the area that is common to both the Downtown Management Authority District and the Maryland Enterprise Zone;
Reservoir Hill Area, within Census Tract 130100, Census Blocks 2001 and 3000;
Jonestown Area, within Census Tract 030200, Census Blocks 1000-1002 and 1014-1016;
W. Cold Spring Lane Area, within Census Tract 130806, Census Blocks 1002-1004 and 1006;
Poppleton Area, within:
Census Tract 180100, Census Blocks 1016, 2015-2017, and 2021; and
Census Tract 180300, Census Blocks 1001-1002 and 1004-1006;
York Road Area, within:
Bel Air Road Area, within:
Census Tract 260102, Census Blocks 4000-4002, 5000, 5002, and 5005- 5008;
Station North Area, within:
Census Tract 110200, Census Block 1000;
Census Tract 120400, Census Block 1010;
Census Tract 120600, Census Blocks 3012-3022; and
Census Tract 120700, Census Blocks 3026-3027.

para.heading: Additional requirements.
para.text: A property tax credit granted under this section shall:
be subject to eligibility requirements no less stringent than those applicable to credits authorized under State Tax-Property Article § 9-242;
be for a period of 15 years for each property, starting with the first assessment after issuance of an occupancy permit for the completed project;
be fully transferrable to a new owner for the remaining life of the credit; and
terminate if, during the credit period, the project:
fails to maintain its high-performance rating; or
no longer qualifies as a market-rate rental housing project, as defined in this section.
The property owner shall ensure that, during the credit period, the project for which the credit was granted is:
in full compliance with the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article;
maintains its high-performance rating; and
continues to be used for market-rate rental housing.

At the time of application for the credit, the property owner must submit a statement of projected economic impact and public benefits for the project. 3 years from the date an application is accepted, the owner must submit statements of actual economic impact and public benefits for the project. Public benefit measures include neighborhood revitalization impact, job creation, tax generation, and minority business development.

para.heading: No tax subsidy duplication allowed.
para.text: Except for the Maryland State Enterprise Zone Tax Credit Program, the tax credit authorized by this section does not apply to any property for which any other tax subsidy from the City, whether in the form of a tax credit, payment in lieu of taxes, tax incremental financing, or otherwise, is being received or has been applied for.
The owner shall submit the application for the tax credit to the Finance Department, with a copy to the Office of Sustainability, and pay the application fee set by the Board of Estimates.
If the property is transferred at any time, the new owner shall file an application to continue the credit.

para.heading: Administration.
para.text: The Director of Finance may:

subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this section, including procedures for granting partial credits for eligibility for less than a full taxable year;
settle disputed claims arising in connection with the credit authorized by this section; and
delegate powers, duties, or functions in connection with the administration of the credit authorized by this section to any employee or agency of the City.
The Department of Finance shall establish review procedures for the program.
The Department of Finance shall analyze data submitted under subsection (f)(2) of this section.

para.heading: Termination of program.
para.text: Applications for the credit may not be accepted after December 31, 2017.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: High-performance.
para.text: "High-performance" means meeting the performance standards set forth in State Tax-Property Article § 9-242(a) {"'High performance building' defined"}.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Newly constructed dwelling" means residential real property:
that has not been previously occupied since its construction; and
for which the building permit for construction was issued on or after October 1, 1994.

para.heading: Inclusion.
para.text: "Newly constructed dwelling" includes a vacant dwelling that:
has been rehabilitated in compliance with applicable local laws and regulations; and
has not been previously occupied since the rehabilitation.

para.heading: Owner.
para.text: "Owner" has the meaning stated in State Tax-Property Article § 9-304(d) {"Newly constructed dwellings"}.

para.heading: Vacant dwelling.
para.text: "Vacant dwelling" means residential real property that:
contains no more than 4 dwelling units as defined in § 202.2 of the Baltimore City Building Code; and
either:
had been cited with a vacant building notice that remained unabated until the rehabilitation described in paragraph (3)(ii)(A); or
has been owned by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City for 1 year and is in need of substantial repair to comply with applicable City codes.

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: There is established a property tax credit, as authorized in State Tax-Property Article § 9-242, against the property tax imposed on high-performance newly constructed dwellings that are owned by qualifying owners.

para.heading: Qualifications.
para.text: The owner of a high-performance newly constructed dwelling may qualify for the tax credit authorized by this section by:
purchasing a high-performance newly constructed dwelling;
occupying that dwelling as his or her principal residence;
filing an application for the credit within 90 days after settling on the purchase of the dwelling;
for each taxable year for which the credit is sought, filing a state income tax return as a resident of Baltimore City;
satisfying all other conditions imposed by the regulations of the Director of Finance; and
not currently receiving the credit authorized by § 10-5 of this subtitle {"Newly constructed dwellings"}.

para.heading: Amount of credit.
para.text: A property tax credit granted under this section shall equal the amount of City property tax imposed on the real property, less the amount of any other credit applicable in that year, multiplied by:
50% for the 1st full taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
40% for then 2nd full taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
30% for the 3rd full taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
20% for the 4th full taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit;
10% for the 5th full taxable year in which the property qualifies for the tax credit; and
0% for each taxable year thereafter.

Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance shall adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this section.
These regulations shall include procedures necessary and appropriate for the submission of an application for and the granting of a property tax credit under this section.

para.heading: Reporting credits.
para.text: The estimated amount of all tax credits received by owners under this section in any fiscal year:
shall be reported by the Director of Finance of Baltimore City as a "tax expenditure" for that fiscal year; and
shall be included in the publication of the City's budget for any subsequent fiscal year with the estimated or actual City property tax revenue for the applicable fiscal year.

para.heading: Annual report.
para.text: The Director of Finance shall report annually to the Board of Estimates and to the Mayor and City Council any results and findings of any analysis of the tax credit, including the steps taken and proposed to be taken to promote and otherwise further the use of the tax credit program.

para.heading: Termination of program.
para.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, additional owners whose settlement on the purchase of a high-performance newly constructed dwelling occurs after June 30, 2027, may not apply for a credit under this section.

para.text: Definitions.
In general.
In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
"Affordable unit" means a dwelling unit that is required by City Code Article 13, Subtitle 2B {"Inclusionary Housing Requirements"} to be provided to a family earning an income that is either:
low income;
moderate income;
very low income; or
extremely low income.

para.heading: AMI.
para.text: "AMI" means the area median income for the metropolitan region that encompasses Baltimore City, as published and annually updated by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.
"Extremely low income" means a household income below 30% AMI.
High-performance.
"High-performance" means a high-performance building as defined in State Tax-Property Article § 9-242 {"High performance buildings"}.
"Low income" means a household income at or below 60% AMI.
Market-rate rental housing project.
"Market-rate rental housing project" means a multi-family dwelling:
that contains 20 or more rental units; and

in which none of the rental units are subject to governmental restrictions on the amount of rent charged or on the tenant's income level, except to the extent specifically required by City Code Article 13, Subtitle 2B {"Inclusionary Housing Requirements"}.
"Moderate income" means a household income at or below 80% AMI.
Newly constructed or converted.
"Newly constructed or converted" means a high-performance market-rate rental housing project:
that is either:
newly constructed on a vacant lot, cleared site, or parking lot;
converted from a non-residential use; or
a wholly renovated structure; and
for which:
the cost of the construction or conversion exceeds $60,000 per rental unit; and
a 1st occupancy permit following substantial completion of the construction or conversion is issued after January 1, 2024.
"Very low income" means a household income at or below 50% AMI.
Program goal.
The goal of this program is to facilitate those inclusionary housing requirements established under Article 13, Subtitle 2B {"Inclusionary Housing Requirements"} of the City Code.
Credit granted.

In accordance with State Tax - Property Article § 9-242 {"High performance buildings"}, a High-Performance Inclusionary Housing Tax Credit is granted against the City property tax imposed on eligible newly constructed or converted high-performance market-rate rental housing projects that provide affordable units as required by Article 13, Subtitle 2B {"Inclusionary Housing Requirements"} of the City Code.

The tax credit described in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph shall be equal to the actual amount of the difference between the market rate rent and the rental rate for each affordable unit in the months in which that affordable unit was rented.

The tax credit detailed in paragraph (1) of this subsection commences with the first full year tax bill issued for the property after the Department of Finance has received a complete application for the tax credit and documentation of the actual rent charged in the prior year for the completed project.
The accounting year for the calculation of the difference between the market rate rent and the rent for each affordable unit is January 1 to December 31 of each calendar year.
All accounting required under this subtitle shall be submitted to the Department of Finance by January 15 following the termination of the previous accounting year.
The amount of the tax credit described under subsection (c)(1) of this section shall be deducted from the next July property tax bill after verification by the Department of Finance.
Credit limits.
The tax credit granted under this section may not, alone or combined with any other credit, exceed the amount of the property tax imposed on the property in any tax year.
The tax credit granted under this section only applies to the required units outlined in City Code Article 13, Subtitle 2B.
Eligibility requirements.
To receive the tax credit, the owner of the high-performance market-rate rental housing project must:
apply to the Department of Finance for the credit in the form and format required under paragraph (2) of this subsection;
provide the Department of Finance an accounting of how many rental units are set aside as affordable units;
demonstrate to the Department of Finance compliance with Article 13, Subtitle 2B {"Inclusionary Housing Requirements"} of the City Code; and
demonstrate to the Department of Finance the difference between the market rent that would have been charged for a market rate rental unit and the rent charged for an affordable unit.
Application.
The owner shall:
submit the application for the tax credit to the Department of Finance in the form and format required by the Department of Finance; and
pay the application fee as set by the Board of Estimates.
If the property is transferred at any time, the new owner shall file an application to continue the credit in the form required by the Department of Finance.
The tax credit granted under this section does not apply to any project that proposes more than 20% of its units be set aside for renters earning 60% of AMI or below.
Additional requirements.
A tax credit granted under this section shall:
be subject to eligibility requirements no less stringent than those applicable to credits authorized under State Tax – Property Article § 9-242 {"High performance buildings"};

before a period of 30 years for each property, starting with the first full year tax bill issued for the property after the Department of Finance has received a complete application for the tax credit and documentation of the actual rent charged in the prior year for the completed project
be fully transferrable to a new owner for the remaining credit period; and
terminate if, during the credit period, the project:
fails to maintain its high-performance rating; or
fails to provide the affordable units required by Article 13, Subtitle 2B {"Inclusionary Housing Requirements"} of the City Code.
Continuing eligibility.
The property owner shall ensure that, during the credit period, the project for which the credit was granted is:
in full compliance with the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article;
maintains its high-performance rating; and
continues to provide affordable units as required by Article 13, Subtitle 2B {"Inclusionary Housing Requirements"} of the City Code.
Tax subsidy duplication allowed.
The tax credit authorized by this section may apply to any property for which any other tax subsidy from the City is being received or has been applied for, whether:
in the form of a tax credit,
in the form of a payment in lieu of taxes agreement; or
in form of tax increment financing.
Administration.
The Director of Finance may:
subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act - Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this section;
settle disputed claims arising in connection with the credit authorized by this section; and
delegate powers, duties, or functions in connection with the administration of the credit authorized by this section to any employee or agency of the City.
Annual report.
Each fiscal year, the estimated amount of all tax credits received by property owners under this section:
shall be reported by the Director of Finance as a tax expenditure; and
shall be included by the Department of Finance in the City's budget publications for any subsequent fiscal year with the estimated or actual City property tax revenue.
On or before July 1 of each year, the Director of Finance shall submit a report that includes an analysis of the tax credit and its findings to the:
Board of Estimates;
Mayor; and
City Council.
Every 2 years the Department of Finance and the Department of Housing and Community Development shall conduct a study and submit a report to the Board of Estimates, Mayor, and City Council that:
evaluates the impact of the tax credit established by this section;
states a conclusion about whether the program goal established in subsection (b) of this section is being met; and
makes recommendations to modify this section to better meet the program goal.
Termination of program.

The Department of Finance may accept applications for the credit for a period of time that is concurrent with the term of the inclusionary housing requirements established by Article 13, Subtitle 2B {"Inclusionary Housing Requirements"} of the City Code.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following words have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Sustainability Office.
para.text: "Sustainability Office" means the Baltimore City Office of Sustainability, established by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 34.

para.heading: Urban agricultural property.
para.text: "Urban agricultural property" has the meaning stated in State Tax-Property Article, § 9-253.

para.heading: Urban agricultural purposes.
para.text: "Urban agricultural purposes" has the meaning stated in State Tax-Property Article, § 9-253.

para.heading: Value.
para.text: "Value" means the amount equal to:
the gross income that is actually received from sales of plants, plant products, animals, or animal products produced on site; or

for plants, plant products, animals, or animal products that are distributed free or at less than applicable market prices, the gross income that could reasonably be assumed to be received from their sale at market prices.

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: In accordance with State Tax-Property Article § 9-253, a tax credit is granted against the City property tax imposed on qualified urban agricultural properties.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: To qualify for the credit granted by this section, a parcel of land:
must be an urban agricultural property that is being used for urban agricultural purposes;
may not be used for any other purpose that would subject the parcel to property tax liability;
must be maintained in full compliance with the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article; and

unless a waiver is granted under paragraph (3) of this subsection, must produce and either sell or otherwise distribute each tax year plants, plant products, animals, or animal products with an aggregate value of $5,000 or more.

para.heading: Documentation of product value.
para.text: The Sustainability Office may require an owner to verify values by providing copies of sales receipts or invoices and, if relevant, evidence of current market rates.
The Sustainability Office may grant a waiver to the value requirement if, in the tax year for which the credit is being sought, the agricultural use of the property:
is newly established; or
has suffered an unexpected disaster, such as drought, vandalism, or infestation
A waiver may not be granted under this paragraph for more than 2 consecutive tax years.

para.heading: Amount of credit.
para.text: The amount of the credit granted under this section is equal to:
the amount of property tax that would otherwise be due on the property, less
the amount of any other credit applicable to the property in that tax year, multiplied by
A property owner seeking to obtain and annually maintain a credit under this section must:
at least 90 days before the 1st tax year for which the credit is sought, file an application for the credit with the Sustainability Office; and

at least 90 days before each subsequent tax year during the term of the credit, file with the Sustainability Office a certification that the property continues to be used for urban agricultural purposes and to meet all other qualification for the credit.
The application and certification must be in the form and contain the information that the Sustainability Office requires.
The term of the credit is 5 tax years, unless renewed.
On application made no later than 90 days before expiration of the 5-year term, a property owner may apply to renew the credit for another 5 tax years.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: If, at any time during the initial 5-year term of the credit or during a 5-year renewal term, the property ceases to be used for urban agricultural purposes:
the credit granted to the property is terminated; and
the owner of the property is liable for:
all property taxes that would have been due during that 5-year term if the credit had not been granted, plus

a surcharge at the rate of 1% for each month or fraction of a month accounting from the dates that those taxes would have become due had the credit never been granted through the date on which the taxes first became due by application of this subsection,

para.heading: Good-cause waiver of interest and penalties.

para.text: A property owner may apply to the Director of Finance for a waiver of all or part of the surcharge imposed under paragraph (1) of this subsection.
The property owner has the burden to demonstrate that:
the cessation of the property's use for urban agricultural purposes was the result of circumstances beyond the owner's control; and
the owner otherwise meets the requisite criteria for a waiver, as established in the rules and regulations adopted under subsection (h)(1)(ii) of this section.
The Director of Finance shall consult with the Sustainability Office before denying or granting the application for a waiver, in whole or in part.

para.heading: Administration.
para.text: The Director of Finance, after consultation with the Sustainability Office:
shall, subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to carry out this section, including:
the procedures, forms, and documentation required to apply for the credit and to periodically evidence continuing eligibility for the credit; and
the procedures and governing criteria for obtaining a surcharge waiver under subsection (g)(2) of this section;
may settle disputed claims that might arise in connection with the credit; and
may delegate to any other City agency or employee the powers, duties, or functions in connection with the administration of the credit.

para.heading: Analyses and report on costs and benefits.
para.text: The Sustainability Office, after consultation with the Director of Finance, must analyze the public costs and benefits of the credits granted under this section and annually report its findings to the Board of Estimates and the City Council.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Combined income.
para.text: "Combined income" has the meaning stated in State Tax-Property Article § 9-104(a)(3).

para.heading: Dwelling.
para.text: "Dwelling" has the meaning stated in State Tax-Property Article § 9-104(a)(6).

para.heading: Homeowner.
para.text: "Homeowner" has the meaning stated in State Tax-Property Article § 9-104(a)(9).

para.heading: State Homeowners' Tax Credit Program.
para.text: "State Homeowners' Tax Credit Program" means the Homeowners' Property Tax Credit Program established by State Tax-Property Article § 9-104.

para.heading: Total real property tax.
para.text: "Total real property tax" has the meaning stated in State Tax-Property Article § 9-104(a)(13).

para.heading: Supplement granted.
para.text: In accordance with State Tax-Property Article § 9-215, a City supplement to the State Homeowners' Tax Credit Program is granted for eligible dwellings.

para.heading: Eligibility requirements.
para.text: A dwelling is eligible for the City supplemental tax credit if:
the dwelling is eligible for participation in the State Homeowners' Tax Credit Program; and
as of the end of the calendar year immediately preceding the taxable year for which the supplemental credit is sought, the dwelling's homeowner:
is at least 62 years old;
has resided in the dwelling for at least 10 years; and
has a combined income of less than $40,000.

para.heading: Amount of supplemental credit.
para.text: The City supplemental tax credit for an eligible dwelling is the total real property tax on the dwelling, less:
the property tax credit granted for the dwelling under State Tax-Property Article § 9-104; and
the aggregate of the following percentages of the homeowner's combined income:
0% of the 1st $12,000 of combined income;
3% of the next $4,000 of combined income;
7% of the next $4,000 of combined income; and
9% of combined income over $20,000.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Dwelling.
para.text: "Dwelling" has the meaning stated in State Tax-Property Article § 9-105 {"Homestead tax credit"}.

para.heading: Finance Director.
para.text: "Finance Director" means the Director of the City Department of Finance or that Director's designee.

para.heading: Homeowner.
para.text: "Homeowner" has the meaning stated in State Tax-Property Article § 9-105 {"Homestead tax credit"}.

para.heading: Homestead dwelling.
para.text: "Homestead dwelling" means a dwelling that is:
located in Baltimore City;
owned by and used as the principal residence of a public safety officer; and
otherwise eligible for the tax credit authorized by State Tax-Property Article § 9-105{"Homestead tax credit"}.

para.heading: Public safety officer.
para.text: "Public safety officer" means a firefighter, an emergency medical technician, or a law enforcement officer who is a sworn member of and employed full time by:
the Baltimore City Fire Department;
the Baltimore City Police Department;
the Baltimore City Sheriff's Office; or
the Baltimore City Public School System.

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: In accordance with State Tax-property Article § 9-304(i), a real property tax credit is granted against the City property tax imposed on the homestead dwelling of a public safety officer.

para.heading: Amount of credit.
para.text: In any taxable year, the amount of the credit granted to a homestead dwelling under this section is the lesser of:
the amount of the property tax imposed on the dwelling.

para.heading: Limitation on other credits.
para.text: In any taxable year for which a property receives a credit granted under this section, the property may not receive any other property tax credit provided by Baltimore City except:
the local portion of the credit authorized by State Tax-Property Article § 9-105 {"Homestead tax credit"}; and
the credit authorized by State Tax-Property Article § 9-221 {"Offsetting income tax rates"}.
A public safety officer seeking to obtain and annually maintain a credit under this section must:
at least 90 days before the 1st tax year for which the credit is sought, file with the Finance Director an application for the credit; and
at least 90 days before each subsequent tax year, file with the Finance Director a verification that:
the homeowner continues to serve as a public safety officer; and
the property continues to be:
used as the public safety officer's principal residence; and
otherwise eligible for the tax credit authorized by this section.
The application and annual verification must be in the form and contain the information that the Finance Director requires.
The credit granted under this section continues from tax year to tax year, subject to:
compliance with the annual verification requirements of subsection (e) of this section; and
termination under paragraph (2) of this subsection.
If, at any time during a tax year, the homeowner ceases to serve as a public safety officer:
the tax credit granted under this section for that tax year is terminated; and
the homeowner is liable for all property taxes that would have been due for that tax year had the credit not been granted, payable as provided in the rules and regulations adopted under this section.

para.heading: Administration.
para.text: The Finance Director:

shall, subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to carry out this section, including procedures, forms, and documentation required to apply for the credit authorized by this section and to periodically verify continuing eligibility for the credit;
in those rules and regulations, may define or further define any terms used in connection with the qualifications for or computation of the credit authorized by this section;
may settle disputed claims arising in connection with the credit authorized by this section;
must prepare an annual written report to the Mayor and City Council detailing the number of public safety officers from each agency who have utilized the tax credit in the preceding year; and
may delegate to any other City agency or employee the Director's powers, duties, or functions in connection with the administration of the credit authorized by this section.

para.heading: Criminal penalties.
para.text: Any person who knowingly makes a false statement on or in connection with an application for a tax credit under this section or in connection with any report or statement supporting a property's continued eligibility for a tax credit granted under this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Termination of program.
para.text: Applications for this credit may not be accepted after June 30, 2028.
