owns a dwelling located in Baltimore City.

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: In accordance with State Tax-Property Article § 9-304(k), a real property tax credit is granted against the City property tax imposed on the homestead dwelling of a low-income employee.

para.heading: Amount of credit.
para.text: In any taxable year, the amount of the credit granted to a homestead dwelling under this section is the lesser of:
the amount of the property tax imposed on the building.

para.heading: Limitation on other credits.
para.text: In any taxable year for which a property receives a credit granted under this section, the property may not receive any other property tax credit provided by Baltimore City except:
the local portion of the credit authorized by State Tax-Property Article § 9-105 {"Homestead tax credit"}; and
the credit authorized by State Tax-Property Article § 9-221 {"Offsetting income tax rates"}.

To determine whether an individual qualifies as a low-income employee as defined by this section, the Finance Department, in consultation with the Department of Human Resources, shall use an individual's annual rate of pay for the calendar year most recently completed prior to the tax year for which the credit is sought.
The Finance Department shall notify employees that their income may qualify them for the tax credit authorized by this subtitle no later than January 30 of the tax year.

para.heading: Additional eligibility requirements.
para.text: In addition to meeting the other requirements provided in this section, to be eligible for a tax credit under this section, the low-income employee must, as of the March 31 of the calendar year in which the application is filed:
have been continuously employed with the City for the preceding 9 months;
have worked a minimum of 1,125 hours during that time; and
have been classified as a regular, full-time employee by the Department of Human Resources.
A low-income employee seeking to obtain and annually maintain a credit under this section must file with the Finance Director an application for the credit.
The application must be filed with the Finance Director on or after February 1 preceding the tax year for which the credit is sought but no later than March 31 of that tax year.
The application must be in the form and contain the information that the Finance Director requires and shall include a verification that:
the homeowner is a regular, full-time City employee; and
the property is:
used as the low-income employee's principal residence; and
otherwise eligible for the tax credit authorized by this section.

para.heading: Term of credit.
para.text: The credit granted under this section continues from tax year to tax year, subject to compliance with the annual verification requirements of subsection (g) of this section.

para.heading: Administration.
para.text: The Finance Director:

shall, subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to carry out this section, including procedures, forms, and documentation required to apply for the credit authorized by this section and to periodically verify continuing eligibility for the credit;
may, in those rules and regulations, define or further define any terms used in connection with the qualifications for or computation of the credit authorized by this section;
may settle disputed claims arising in connection with the credit authorized by this section;
must prepare an annual written report to the Mayor and City Council detailing the number of low-income employees from each agency who have utilized the tax credit in the preceding year; and
may delegate to any other City agency or employee the Director's powers, duties, or functions in connection with the administration of the credit authorized by this section.

para.heading: Criminal penalties.
para.text: Any person who knowingly makes a false statement on or in connection with an application for a tax credit under this section or in connection with any report or statement supporting a property's continued eligibility for a tax credit granted under this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Termination of program.
para.text: Applications for this credit may not be accepted after June 30, 2030.

section.heading: Food Desert Incentive Areas (Personal Property Tax Credit).

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Finance Director.
para.text: "Finance Director" means the Director of the City Department of Finance or that Director's designee.

para.heading: Food desert.
para.text: "Food desert" means an area in which:
the distance to a supermarket is more than ¼ mile;
the median household income is at or below 185% of the Federal Poverty Level, as measured by the most recent 5-year estimate of the U.S. Census Bureau's American Community Survey;
over 30% of households have no vehicle available, as measured by the most recent 5-year estimate of the U.S. Census Bureau's American Community Survey; and
the Healthy Food Availability Index average score of all food stores is low, as measured by the Johns Hopkins Center for a Liveable Future.

para.heading: Food Desert Incentive Area.
para.text: "Food Desert Incentive Area" means any area:
that is a food desert;
that is within ¼ mile of a food desert; or
that would be a food desert but for the presence of a qualified supermarket.

para.heading: Personal property.
para.text: "Personal property" means any personal property that is subject to the City's tax on personal property.

para.heading: Qualified supermarket.
para.text: "Qualified supermarket' means a supermarket that has been newly constructed or newly substantially renovated to meet the qualifications imposed by this subtitle.

para.heading: Supermarket.
para.text: "Supermarket" means a grocery store that has:
all major food departments, including produce, meat, seafood, dairy, and canned and packaged goods;
more than 50% of total sales derived from food sales; and
more than 50% of total floor space dedicated to food sales.

para.heading: Credit granted.
para.text: In accordance with State Tax-Property Article § 9-304(h), a tax credit is granted against the City personal property tax imposed on qualified supermarkets.

para.heading: Qualifications for credit.
para.text: To qualify for the credit granted by this section, a qualified supermarket must:
be located in a Food Desert Incentive Area;
have at least 500 square feet of total floor space dedicated to the sale of fruits and vegetables;
have at least 500 square feet of total floor space dedicated to the sale of other perishable goods, including meat, seafood, and dairy products; and
have expended on new personal property:
for a newly constructed supermarket, an amount equal to the greater of:
$25 per square foot of total floor space; or
for a newly substantially renovated supermarket, an amount based on the supermarket's total floor space, as follows:

tr.td: More than 20,000 sq. ft. up to 45,000 sq. ft.

para.heading: Amount of credit.
para.text: The amount of the credit granted under this section is equal to:
the amount of personal property tax that would otherwise be due in the current tax year on the supermarket's personal property, less
the amount of any other credit applicable in the current tax year to the personal property, multiplied by

para.heading: Application.
para.text: The owner of the personal property for which a credit under this section is being sought must file an application with the Finance Director at least 90 days before the 1st tax year for which the credit is sought.

para.heading: Term of credit.
para.text: The term of the credit is 10 tax years.

para.heading: Continuing eligibility.
para.text: The owner of the personal property for which a credit has been granted under this section shall ensure that, throughout the credit period, the supermarket:
continues to operate as a supermarket; and
is maintained in full compliance with:
the City Health Article; and
the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article.

para.heading: Administration.
para.text: The Finance Director, after consultation with the Baltimore Development Corporation:

shall, subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to carry out this section, including procedures, forms, and documentation required to apply for the credit authorized by this section and to periodically evidence continuing eligibility for the credit;
in those rules and regulations, may define or further define any terms used in connection with the qualifications for or computation of the credit authorized by this section;
may settle disputed claims arising in connection with the credit authorized by this section; and

may delegate to any other City agency or to the Baltimore Development Corporation any of her or his ministerial powers, duties, or functions in connection with the administration of the credit authorized by this section.

section.heading: Energy Conservation Devices (Real Property Tax Credit).

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Dwelling" means a house that is:
used as the principal residence of the homeowner; and

actually occupied or expected to be occupied by the homeowner for more than 6 months of a 12-month period beginning with the date of finality for the taxable year for which the property tax credit under this section is sought.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Dwelling" includes:
a condominium unit that is occupied by an individual who has legal interest in the condominium;
an apartment in a cooperative apartment corporation that is occupied by an individual who has legal interest in the apartment; and
a part of real property used other than primarily for residential purposes, if the real property is used as a principal residence by an individual who has a legal interest in the real property.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Dwelling" does not include the lot or curtilage on which the house, condominium, apartment, or other improvement is erected.

para.heading: Eligible costs.
para.text: "Eligible costs" means reasonable costs incurred:
within the 12 months before the initial application for the credit;
for the purchase or lease of a solar energy device or geothermal energy device, including any part, component, or accessory equipment necessary to operate the device; and
associated with installation of the solar energy device or the geothermal energy device.

para.heading: Geothermal energy device.
para.text: "Geothermal energy device" means an energy conserving device that:
uses geothermal energy to heat or cool a structure or to provide hot water for use in the structure; and
meets national safety and performance standards set by a nationally recognized testing laboratory for that type of device.

para.heading: House.
para.text: "House" means a structure that has been adapted for overnight accommodation of an individual.

para.heading: Principal residence.
para.text: "Principal residence" means the one dwelling where an individual regularly resides and is the location designated by the individual for the legal purpose of voting, obtaining a driver's license, and filing income tax returns.

para.heading: Solar energy device.
para.text: "Solar energy device" means an energy conserving device that:
uses solar energy to heat or cool a structure, to generate electricity to be used in the structure, or to provide hot water for use in the structure; and
meets national safety and performance standards set by a nationally recognized testing laboratory for that type of device.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In accordance with State Tax-Property Article § 9-203, a tax credit is granted against the City portion of real property tax on a dwelling to which a solar energy device or geothermal energy device is installed and in use.

para.heading: Limitation.
para.text: The City may not grant more than 1 tax credit for each dwelling.

para.heading: Qualifications.
para.text: The owner of a dwelling that uses a solar energy device or geothermal energy device may qualify for the tax credit authorized by this section by:
filing a state income tax return as a resident of Baltimore City for each taxable year for which the credit is sought;
filing an application for the credit with the Director of the Department of Finance; and
satisfying all other conditions imposed by the regulations of the Director of the Department of Finance.

para.heading: Amount of credit.
para.text: The credit against the City portion of real property tax on a dwelling under this section is the lesser of:
50% of the eligible costs up to a maximum of $5,000; or
50% of the eligible costs up to a maximum of $1,500 for either a solar energy device or geothermal energy device installed exclusively to provide hot water for use in the dwelling.

para.heading: Credit not to exceed property tax.
para.text: The amount of a credit applied in a tax year may not exceed the amount of City real property tax imposed on the dwelling in that tax year.

para.heading: Tax credit period.
para.text: The tax credit granted under this section applies in the taxable year immediately following the submission of an application.

para.heading: Transfer of credit.
para.text: The tax credit granted under this section is transferable to a subsequent owner if:
the transfer is within the 1-year credit eligibility period; and
the solar energy device or geothermal energy device remains in use in the dwelling.

para.heading: Application.
para.text: The application must be in the form and contain the information that the Director of the Department of Finance requires.

para.heading: Administration.
para.text: The Director of the Department of Finance or the Director's designee:

shall, subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to carry out this section, including procedures, forms, and documentation required to apply for the credit authorized by this section; and
may settle disputed claims arising in connection with the credit authorized by this section.

para.heading: Reporting credits.
para.text: The estimated amount of all tax credits received by owners under this section in any fiscal year shall be:
reported by the Director of the Department of Finance as a "tax expenditure" for that fiscal year; and
included in the publication of the City's budget for any subsequent fiscal year with the estimated or actual City property tax revenue for the applicable fiscal year.

para.heading: Annual report.
para.text: The Director of the Department of Finance or the Director's designee must report annually to the Board of Estimates and to the Mayor and City Council any results and findings of any analysis of the tax credit, including the steps taken and proposed to be taken to promote and further the use of the tax credit program.

para.heading: Termination of tax credit.
para.text: The Department of Finance may not accept applications for the tax credit granted under this section after June 30, 2028.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following words have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Building.
para.text: “Building” has the meaning stated in City Code Article 13, § 11-1 {“Definitions”}.

para.heading: Property owner.
para.text: “Property owner” means the person who holds the title to a vacant structure.

para.heading: Vacant structure.
para.text: “Vacant structure” has the meaning stated in § 116.4 of the Baltimore City Building Code.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A property classified by the Department of Housing and Community Development as a vacant structure is subject to:

in the first full tax year the property is classified as a vacant structure, 3 times the full rate property tax established by City Charter Article VI, § 7(c) {“Enactment of Ordinance of Estimates: Revenue ordinances”}; and
any tax year thereafter that the property is classified as a vacant structure, 4 times the full rate property tax.

para.heading: First tax year.
para.text: The first tax year when the property tax described in paragraph (1) of this subsection may be applied in the July 1, 2026 to June 30, 2027 tax year.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {“Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations”} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance and the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development shall adopt rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The City Administrator or the City Administrator’s designee shall notify an owner of real property located within the City limits of the implementation of the tax established by this subtitle 11 by the following methods:
United States mail;
advertisement in 2 newspapers in general circulation for a minimum of 2 consecutive weeks during each month of June preceding the tax years listed below; and
posting on the City website.

para.heading: Notice by mail.
para.text: To comply with paragraph (1)(i) of this subsection the City Administrator or the City Administrator’s designee may include the notice required by paragraph (1) of this subsection with:
a water bill; or
a violation notice for a vacant structure issued by the Department of Housing and Community Development.

para.heading: Reporting.
para.text: On or before December 1 of each year, the Department of Finance shall submit to the Mayor and City Council, and in accordance with § 6-302(c)(2) of the State Tax – Property Article, the Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development, and the Maryland General Assembly, a report that includes the following:
the special rate set under State Tax – Property Article § 6-302(c)(1);
the number of properties to which the special tax rate applies;
the revenue change resulting from the special rate;
the use of the revenue from the special rate;
whether properties subject to the special rate are viable for adaptive reuse, as defined in § 1-102 of the State Housing and Community Development Article; and
any existing plans to convert properties viable for adaptive reuse.

container.heading: Payments in Lieu of Taxes: Hotel Facilities in Urban Renewal Areas

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: City-owned property.
para.text: "City-owned property" means any ownership interest held by the City in the applicable real property, including legal title to the property, whether in fee or as a leasehold interest, whether or not subject to a ground lease, and whether now owned or later acquired by the City.

para.heading: Enabling Law.
para.text: "Enabling Law" means § 7-501 of the State Tax-Property Article.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Hotel facilities" means any land and improvements thereon, or a portion thereof, that:
is to be constructed for the use and operation as a hotel for short-term guest rentals; and
has a minimum investment of $50,000,000 of private capital.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Hotel facilities" includes related meeting facilities, banquet facilities, dining facilities, associated public or private parking facilities, and other related service facilities.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Hotel facilities" does not include any City-owned property that is used, in whole or part, for the conduct of gaming or gambling activities.

para.heading: PILOT.
para.text: "PILOT" means negotiated payments in lieu of taxes, as authorized by the Enabling Law.

para.heading: PILOT Agreement.
para.text: "PILOT Agreement" means an agreement providing for negotiated payments in lieu of taxes, as authorized by this subtitle.

section.heading: Findings and determinations.
section.text: The Mayor and City Council finds and determines that:

para.text: there is a need for additional hotel facilities in the urban renewal areas of the City to provide a positive atmosphere for the tourism and convention businesses; and

the authorization of a PILOT in connection with any lease of City-owned property entered into on or after January 1, 1998, for hotel facilities in an urban renewal area will substantially aid in achieving and encouraging economic development in the City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Acting pursuant to the Enabling Law, the City is authorized to exempt from municipal taxation hotel facilities:
that are on City-owned property within any urban renewal area; and
that, on or after January 1, 1998, are leased or otherwise made available to any person:
who uses the property in connection with a business that is conducted for profit; and
who is authorized to accept a PILOT in accordance with the terms and conditions of a PILOT Agreement.

para.heading: Inclusion in assessable base.
para.text: Provided, however, that the assessment of these hotel facilities shall be included in the assessable base of the City to determine the amount of any State of Maryland aid that is based on the assessable base of the City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The City is authorized to negotiate a PILOT Agreement in connection with any lease after January 1, 1998, of any City-owned property within any urban renewal area for use as hotel facilities.

However, the economic terms to be incorporated into any PILOT Agreement must be approved by an Ordinance of the Mayor and City Council before the Board of Estimates gives final approval to the PILOT Agreement.
Each PILOT Agreement:
shall conform to the economic terms approved by an Ordinance of the Mayor and City Council; and

shall contain any additional terms that the Board of Estimates deems reasonably necessary to accomplish the purposes of this subtitle, taking into account the specific needs of the particular hotel facility.
All PILOT Agreements executed pursuant to this subtitle must provide that the PILOT Agreement will terminate immediately if the property is no longer used as a hotel facility.

section.heading: Board of Estimates to set final terms.
section.text: The final terms of any PILOT Agreement or disposition agreement affecting any hotel facility and the final forms of all documents drafted in connection with it, are subject to the approval of the Board of Estimates.

section.heading: Tax imposed.
section.text: Pursuant to State Tax-Property Article § 12-103(b), the rate of tax applicable to instruments recorded with the Clerk of the Circuit Court for Baltimore City is:

para.text: in the case of instruments conveying title to property, $5 for each $500 or fractional part of $500 of the actual consideration paid or to be paid; and
in the case of instruments securing a debt, $5 for each $500 or fractional part of $500 of the principal amount of the debt secured.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The tax imposed by this subtitle does not apply to the first $22,000 of the consideration payable on the conveyance of owner-occupied residential property if the instrument in writing is accompanied by a statement, signed under oath by the buyer, that the buyer will use the property as the buyer's principal residence by actually occupying the property for at least 7 months of the 12-month period immediately following the conveyance.

Except as specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the buyer shall receive the entire exemption provided by this section, irrespective of (i) any contractual provisions concerning the division of taxes between the buyer and the seller and (ii) the presumption under State Real Property Article § 14-104(b) {"Division of ... Tax: Presumption"}.

The seller shall receive the entire exemption provided by this section if (i) the seller has agreed by contract to pay the entire amount of the tax imposed by this subtitle or (ii) the seller is responsible for paying the entire amount of the tax under State Real Property Article § 14-104(c) {"Division of ... Tax: First-time Maryland Home-buyers"}.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: As used herein, the following definitions shall apply.

"Estate" means real property and chattels real of every description, including, but not limited to, fee simple estate, leasehold estate, limited estate, and legal and equitable interests in real property.
But the term "estate" specifically does not include land installment contracts, such a contract for the purposes of this subtitle being defined as a legally binding executory agreement under which:
the vendor agrees to sell an interest in property to the vendee and the vendee agrees to pay the purchase price in 5 or more subsequent payments exclusive of any down payment; and
the vendor retains title as security for the vendee's obligation.

para.heading: Estate of inheritance.
para.text: "Estate of inheritance" means any estate which may descend to heirs, otherwise known as an estate in fee simple.

para.heading: Mortgage.
para.text: The term "mortgage" as used in this subtitle, shall include deeds of trust made to secure the repayment of indebtedness.

para.heading: Transfer.
para.text: "Transfer" means the acts of the parties, or of the law, by which the title to any estate of inheritance or freehold, or any declaration or limitation of use, or any estate above 7 years, is conveyed from 1 person to another.

A tax is hereby levied and imposed upon the transfer of any estate of inheritance or freehold, of any declaration or limitation of use, or any estate above 7 years, in Baltimore City, at the rate of 1½% of the taxable basis thereof, as hereinafter defined.

Except that the tax levied and imposed hereunder shall not apply to any lease or sublease for an initial term of not more than 7 years which contains any provisions for renewal for 1 or more succeeding stated terms of not more than 7 years each, if under such provision for renewal the right to effect or prevent each such renewal term shall be optional with either the landlord or the tenant.

para.heading: When payable.
para.text: Said tax shall be payable before the written instrument intending to effect such transfer shall be offered to the Clerk of the Circuit Court for Baltimore City for recordation.
The payment of the tax levied and imposed hereunder:
shall be made to the Director of Finance of Baltimore City, at a place designated by the said Director of Finance; and
shall be evidenced by the affixing of an official receipt upon such written instrument by the Director of Finance or his authorized representative.
Such receipt shall be in such form as may be designated by the Director of Finance.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The tax imposed by this subtitle does not apply to the first $22,000 of the consideration payable on the conveyance of owner-occupied residential property if:
the total consideration payable on the conveyance is less than $250,000; and

the instrument in writing is accompanied by a statement, signed under oath by the buyer, that the buyer will use the property as the buyer's principal residence by actually occupying the property for at least 7 months of the 12-month period immediately following the conveyance.

Except as specified in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the buyer shall receive the entire exemption provided by this subsection (d), irrespective of (A) any contractual provisions concerning the division of taxes between the buyer and the seller and (B) the presumption under State Real Property Article § 14-104(b) {"Division of ... Tax: Presumption"}.

The seller shall receive the entire exemption provided by this subsection (d) if (A) the seller has agreed by contract to pay the entire amount of the tax imposed by this subtitle or (B) the seller is responsible for paying the entire amount of the tax under State Real Property Article § 14-104(c) {"Division of ... Tax: First-time Maryland Home-buyers"}.

Section 3 of Ord. 06-312 provides that it “takes effect July 1, 2007, as to any instrument conveying title or securing a debt that contains a notary acknowledgment dated on or after July 1, 2007, and is presented for recordation on or after July 1, 2007.”

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A tax is hereby levied and imposed upon the transfer of real property affected by filing of articles of sale, lease, exchange, or other transfer of all or substantially all the property and assets of a corporation with respect to the property subject to the certificate required under State Corporations and Associations Article § 3-112, at the rate of 1½% of the taxable basis thereof, as hereinafter defined.
The tax shall be payable pursuant to the provisions of State Tax-Property Article § 13-404.

No written instrument evidencing the transfer of property taxable hereunder shall be received for recording in Baltimore City until the original of the articles of sale, lease, exchange or other transfer shall have been exhibited to the Clerk of the Circuit Court for Baltimore City showing that the tax herein levied and imposed has been paid to the State and, if any additional tax is payable on the written instrument, it has been paid.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No attornment agreement, memorandum of lease, assignment of lease, or other instrument (referred to collectively herein as "other instrument") intended to publicize or giving or intended to give constructive notice of the existence of a lease which has not been recorded but which is taxable hereunder, whether or not such other instrument gives such constructive notice in point of law, shall be received for recording until the original lease shall have been exhibited to the clerk and the tax paid thereon, in addition to whatever tax may be payable on such other instrument.

para.heading: Scope.
para.text: Nothing in this section shall be taken to apply to any lease not taxable under § 17-1 of this subtitle.

para.heading: "Taxable basis" defined.
para.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, "taxable basis" means the cash consideration and the value of any other consideration paid or agreed to be paid for the property transferred, including the amount of any liens or encumbrances on the property other than current property taxes and other municipal charges.

The cash consideration plus the value of any other consideration paid or agreed to be paid for the property, including the amount of liens or encumbrances on the property, shall be stated in a written affidavit, made on personal knowledge of the affiant and under penalties of perjury, on forms to be furnished by the Director of Finance.

The Director of Finance may not accept the affidavit unless it is accompanied by written proof of the purchase price for the property. This proof shall include a copy of the settlement sheet, contract of sale, or other document the Director of Finance finds adequate.
The affidavit and accompanying documents shall be filed with the Director of Finance at the time that the tax is paid.

para.heading: Consideration other than cash, etc. – In general.
para.text: If any part of the consideration paid or agreed to be paid for the property consists of anything other than (i) cash paid or agreed to be paid or (ii) the amount of liens or encumbrances on the property,"taxable basis" means the greater of:
the consideration stated in accordance with subsections (a) and (b) of this section; or
the full cash value of the property, as most recently determined by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

para.heading: Consideration other than cash, etc. – Transfer of ground rent.
para.text: For a transfer of a perpetually renewable ground rent, if any part of the consideration paid or agreed to be paid consists of anything other than (i) cash paid or agreed to be paid or (ii) the amount of liens or encumbrances, "taxable basis" means the greater of:
the consideration stated in accordance with subsections (a) and (b) of this section; or
either:
the redemption value of the ground rent, if redeemable; or
if irredeemable, the capitalization at 5% of the ground rent.

For a lease for a term above 7 years, not perpetually renewable,"taxable basis" means the capitalization at 10% of the average annual base rental for the property over the entire term of the lease, including all renewal terms, plus the cash consideration and the value of any other consideration paid or agreed to be paid, other than the base rent.

If the average annual rental cannot be determined at the time of recording the lease or the attornment agreement, memorandum of lease, assignment of lease, or other instrument intended to give notice of the lease, or if any part of the consideration paid or agreed to be paid for the rental of the property consists of anything other than cash paid or agreed to be paid, the value of which cannot be readily determined, then in either case:

the stipulated cash base rental (excluding indeterminable items of every kind, such as percentage of sales, taxes, maintenance, and repair costs and utilities) shall be used as the basis for tax computation; and
"taxable basis" means the greater of:

the minimum average annual rental ascertainable from the terms of the lease, plus 5% of the minimum average annual rental, the whole to be capitalized at 10%, plus any consideration paid or agreed to be paid, other than rent; or
the full cash value of the property, as most recently determined by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

para.heading: Valuation of life estate.
para.text: The value of life estates subject to the tax levied and imposed by this subtitle shall be determined in the same manner as the value of life estates are determined from time to time, for federal estate tax purposes under the Internal Revenue Code and regulations promulgated thereunder.

para.heading: Valuation of remainders and reversions.
para.text: The remainders and reversions after a life estate or life estates shall be valued by determining the value of the whole and deducting therefrom the value of the preceding estates determined as aforesaid.

section.heading: Property partly outside City.
section.text: In the case of a transfer of property lying partly within and partly without Baltimore City, the tax levied and imposed by this subtitle shall be based only upon the taxable basis of the portion or fractional part of said property which lies within Baltimore City.

section.heading: Exemptions.
section.text: The tax levied and imposed by this subtitle shall not apply to the following:

para.text: where the taxable basis is less than $100;
transfers by way of mortgage securing a debt;
transfers by way of bona fide gift or without any consideration;

transfers to the United States, the State of Maryland, or any political subdivision thereof, or the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, or any instrumentality or agency of said respective bodies politic;

transfers by the Housing Authority of Baltimore City to transferees who, in connection with such transfers, grant mortgages which are insured by the Federal Housing Administration or by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development pursuant to Section 235 of the National Housing Act or successor program of the National Housing Act (12 U.S.C. §1701 et seq.), as amended from time to time;

transfers of property which in the hands of the transferee, immediately after such transfer, shall be entitled to exemption from taxation pursuant to Article 81, § 9 of the Annotated Code of Maryland (1957) {cf. Tax-Property Article, Title 7, Subtitle 1};

a transfer to a mortgagee when the instrument intending to effect such transfer is presented for recording simultaneously with a deed from such mortgagee to the federal or state government or any instrumentality, agency, or political subdivision thereof;

a transfer made for the partitioning in kind between joint owners or undivided interests, provided there is no consideration paid or to be paid in connection with such transfers other than the division of the jointly-owned property;
a transfer under the last will and testament of a decedent, or a transfer to the heirs or next of kin of a decedent under the law of descent and distribution of the State of Maryland;
a transfer made expressly for the purpose of confirming or correcting a transfer previously made, if there is no taxable basis in excess of $100 for such transfer; or
a transfer made expressly for any of the following purposes:

the transfer of title to real property between a subsidiary corporation and its parent corporation for no consideration, for nominal consideration, or in sole consideration of the issue or cancellation or surrender of a subsidiary's stock;

the transfer of title to real property between 2 or more subsidiary corporations wholly owned by the same parent corporation for no consideration, for nominal consideration, or in sole consideration of the issue or the cancellation or surrender of a subsidiary's stock; or

deed made pursuant to reorganizations within the meaning of § 368(a), or in accordance with §§ 371 to 374, inclusive, of the Internal Revenue Code of the United States duly accepted for filing by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

para.heading: Payment required.
para.text: No written instrument intended to effect a transfer which is subject to the tax levied and imposed by this subtitle shall be presented to the Clerk of the Circuit Court for Baltimore City for recordation among the Land Records of Baltimore City unless and until such tax shall have been paid to the Director of Finance.

para.heading: Notations for transfers not subject to tax.
para.text: When the Director of Finance shall determine that a particular transfer is not subject to the tax levied and imposed by this subtitle, he shall so indicate by legend or notation on the written instrument intending to effect such transfer.

section.heading: Interest and civil penalties.
section.text: In the event any written instrument intending to effect a transfer subject to the tax levied and imposed under this subtitle is recorded by the Clerk of the Circuit Court for Baltimore City without such tax having been first paid, the person and/or other legal entity liable for the payment of such tax shall be assessed by the Director of Finance of Baltimore City for:

para.text: the amount of the tax due;
plus interest at the rate of ½% per month, or fractional part thereof, accounting from the date when such written instrument was received for recordation; and
a penalty of 10% of the tax due.

para.heading: Transferors and transferees, jointly and severally.
para.text: The tax levied and imposed by this subtitle, and all increases, interest, and penalties thereon, shall be and become, from the time due and payable, the debt of the legal and equitable transferors and transferees, jointly and severally, of the property affected by or involved in any written instrument intending to effect a transfer subject to such tax.

para.heading: But governmental transferors.
para.text: Except that, in the case of transfers by the United States, the State of Maryland, or any political subdivision thereof, or the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, or any instrumentality or agency of said respective bodies politic, which transfers are not exempt under § 17-7 of this subtitle, the tax levied and imposed by this subtitle, and all increases, interest and penalties thereon, shall be and become, from the time due and payable, the debt of the legal and equitable transferees only, and shall not become the debt of any of the aforementioned bodies politic or any instrumentality or agency thereof.

para.heading: General powers of Director of Finance.
para.text: In order to properly carry out and enforce the provisions of this subtitle and to collect the tax levied and imposed hereunder, the Director of Finance is hereby authorized and empowered:

subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, to make, adopt, promulgate, and amend, from time to time, such rules and regulations as he may deem necessary or proper:
to carry out and enforce the provisions of this subtitle;
to fully collect the tax imposed by this subtitle; and
to define or construe any of the terms and provisions used in this subtitle in connection with the imposition or collection of said tax;
with the approval of the City Solicitor:
to compromise disputed claims in connection with the tax levied and imposed by this subtitle; and
for good and sufficient causes shown, to abate or remit interest and penalties and to rebate and refund any taxes erroneously or improperly paid;

to delegate any of his powers, duties, and functions under the provisions of this subtitle to the City Collector or any other agent, representative, or employee of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore;

to conduct investigations concerning any matter covered by this subtitle and, at any time and in connection therewith, to require by subpoena or summons the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of any books, accounts, records, papers, and correspondence relating to any matter which the Director of Finance is authorized by this subtitle to determine; and
to sign subpoenas, administer oaths, and affirmations, examine witnesses, and receive evidence.

para.heading: Enforcing subpoenas, etc.
para.text: In case of disobedience of any subpoena or the contumacy of any witness appearing before the Director of Finance, or his duly authorized agent or representative, the Director of Finance may apply to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City for an order requiring the person subpoenaed to obey the subpoena or to give evidence or to produce books, accounts, records, papers, and correspondence touching the matter in question.

No person shall be excused from testifying or producing any books, papers, records, or data in any investigation or upon any hearing when ordered to do so by the Director of Finance or his duly authorized agent or representative, upon the ground that the testimony or evidence, documentary or otherwise, may tend to incriminate him or subject him to criminal penalty, but no such testimony or evidence, documentary or otherwise, shall be used in any subsequent prosecution against the individual supplying the same.
No individual so testifying shall be exempt from prosecution and punishment for perjury committed in so testifying.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: Appeal to BMZA.
para.text: In the event that any person or other legal entity who is legally liable for the payment of the tax levied and imposed by this subtitle is aggrieved by any determination, decision, order, or notice of any kind which is made, rendered, issued, or given under the provisions of this subtitle, such person or other legal entity, within 20 days after notice of any such determination, decision, order, or notice has been given to or mailed to such person or other legal entity, shall have the right to appeal therefrom to the Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals for review by it.

para.heading: Consideration by BMZA.
para.text: Upon reasonable notice in accordance with its rules and the provisions of the Baltimore City Charter, the Board:
shall hold a hearing; and
by a majority vote thereof, shall have the power and authority to reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or modify the determination, decision, order, or notice appealed from.

para.heading: Judicial review.
para.text: A person aggrieved by a determination of the Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals under this section may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Appellate review.
para.text: A party to the judicial review may appeal the court's final judgment to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

section.heading: Court Clerk not responsible for collections.
section.text: Nothing contained in this subtitle shall be taken or construed as imposing any duty or liability upon the Clerk of the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in connection with the imposition, payment or collection of the tax imposed by this subtitle, or the administration or enforcement of the provisions of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person or other legal entity who:

willfully offers to the Clerk of the Circuit Court for Baltimore City for recordation or who has recorded any written instrument intending to effect a transfer subject to the tax levied and imposed under this subtitle without first having paid the tax imposed by this subtitle;
willfully misrepresents the amount of value of the consideration constituting the taxable basis in a transfer of property subject to the tax levied and imposed under this subtitle;
participates or aids in any manner in the evasion of the tax levied and imposed by this subtitle;
willfully violates any of the rules or regulations made, adopted or promulgated by the Director of Finance under the provisions of this subtitle; or
willfully violates any of the provisions of this subtitle,
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than $500 for each and every such offense.

para.heading: Forgery.
para.text: Any person who forges or counterfeits any official receipt or legend or the signature of the Director of Finance, or facsimile thereof, or of his duly authorized representative, or who in any manner affixes or causes to be affixed any such forged or counterfeit receipt, legend, or signature to any written instrument intending to effect a transfer subject to the tax levied and imposed under this subtitle, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than $500, or be imprisoned for not more than 6 months, or both, in the discretion of the Court, for each and every such offense.

container.heading: Recordation and Transfer Taxes – Yield Excise Tax

annotations.annotation: This subtitle was enacted by Ordinance 18-215, effective January 11, 2019.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: An excise tax, to be known as the Yield Tax, shall be levied and collected based upon the tax yield from any transaction for which recordation taxes and transfer taxes are due pursuant to Subtitles 16 and 17 of this article.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Yield Tax does not apply to:

any mortgage or deed of trust recorded within 6 months of the effective date of this subtitle and securing a loan the proceeds of which will provide funding for the construction and completion to the issuance of a certificate of use and occupancy of a project and for which a full but not a partial building permit has been issued prior to the effective date of this subtitle; or

any deed and any purchase money mortgage or deed of trust related thereto for the conveyance of a residential property to be occupied by the grantee of such deed and which deed is delivered pursuant to a bona fide contract of sale that has been entered into between the grantor and grantee of such deed within 2 years of the effective date of this subtitle.

para.heading: Supporting affidavit required.
para.text: The facts to substantiate the foregoing exemptions shall be set forth in an affidavit made on personal knowledge of the affiant and under penalties of perjury on forms to be furnished by the Director of Finance and including supporting documents that verify compliance with the requirement for the exemption.

para.heading: Transactions assessed.
para.text: The Yield Tax shall be assessed on those transactions whose value exceeds $1 million, as determined by Subtitles 16 and 17 of this article for the purposes of calculating the recordation and transfer taxes respectively.

annotation.text: This “rate of tax” in this subsection was amended by Ord. 19-233, effective March 19, 2019.
The rate of tax shall be as follows:

para.text: 15% on the amount collected under Subtitle 16 of this article; and
40% on the amount collected under Subtitle 17 of this article.

section.heading: Dedication of tax proceeds.
section.text: Proceeds from the tax imposed by this subtitle up to $16 million, and one-half of the proceeds in excess of $16 million, if any, shall be deposited in the continuing, nonlapsing fund created by City Charter, Article I, § 14 {"Affordable Housing Trust Fund"}, to be used exclusively for the purposes specified in that section, subject to appropriation pursuant to the annual Ordinance of Estimates.

section.heading: Interest and civil penalties.
section.text: In the event that the tax levied and imposed under this subtitle is not paid as required by this subtitle, the person and/or other legal entity liable for the payment of that tax shall be assessed by the Director of Finance for:

para.text: the amount of the tax due;
interest at the rate of ½% for each month or fraction of a month, accounting from the date when such written instrument was received for recordation; and
a penalty of 10% of the tax due.

section.heading: Liability of transferors and transferees.
section.text: The tax levied and imposed by this subtitle, and all increases, interest, and penalties thereon, shall be and become, from the time due and payable, the debt of the legal and equitable transferors and transferees, jointly and severally, of the property subject to the recordation and transfer taxes upon which the Yield Tax is calculated.

section.heading: Administration of subtitle.
section.text: In order to properly carry out and enforce the provisions of this subtitle and to collect the tax levied and imposed by this subtitle, the Director of Finance is hereby authorized and empowered:

para.text: subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, to make, adopt, promulgate, and amend, from time to time, such rules and regulations as he may deem necessary or proper:
to carry out and enforce the provisions of this subtitle;
to fully collect the tax imposed by this subtitle; and
to define or construe any of the terms and provisions used in this subtitle in connection with the imposition or collection of that tax;
with the approval of the City Solicitor:
to compromise disputed claims in connection with the tax levied and imposed by this subtitle; and
for good and sufficient causes shown, to abate or remit interest and penalties and to rebate and refund any taxes erroneously or improperly paid; and
to delegate any of his powers, duties, and functions under the provisions of this subtitle to the City Collector.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

section.heading: Criminal penalties.
section.text: Any person who participates or aids in any manner in the evasion of the tax levied and imposed by this subtitle or who willfully violates any provision of this subtitle or of the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

section.heading: Tax imposed.
section.text: A local income tax is levied and imposed on each resident of Baltimore City.

section.heading: Rate of tax.
section.text: For each calendar year, the tax rate is 3.2% of an individual's Maryland taxable income for that year.

section.heading: Administration.
section.text: The income tax imposed by this subtitle:

para.text: shall be collected in the same manner and at the same time as the income tax imposed by the State is collected; and
shall be administered in accordance with, and subject to, the applicable provisions of the State Tax-General Article.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, there is levied and imposed a tax at the rate of 10% of the gross receipts derived from any admissions and amusement charge as defined in State Tax-General Article § 4-101(b).

para.heading: Theaters on National Register.
para.text: For any theater included on the National Register of Historic Places, the rate shall be 5% of the gross receipts.

para.heading: Single-screen theaters.
para.text: For any single-screen movie theater that rents or leases its motion picture film through commercial distribution, the rate shall be 5% of the gross receipts.

section.heading: Tax on reduced charges.
section.text: In the City of Baltimore, there is levied and imposed a tax on reduced charges or free admissions, as set forth in State Tax-General Article § 4-105(f).

section.heading: Exemptions – Community associations; restaurants.
section.text: The following are exempt from the tax imposed by this subtitle:

para.text: the gross receipts of not-for-profit community associations, as defined in State Tax-General Article § 4-104; and

restaurants that provide entertainment consisting solely of an individual roving performer whose act does not employ and is not dependent on the use of amplified sound for entertaining patrons within the restaurant.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this section, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Arts and entertainment district.
para.text: "Arts and entertainment district" has the meaning stated in State Economic Development Article, § 4-701.

para.heading: Arts and entertainment enterprise.
para.text: "Arts and entertainment enterprise" has the meaning stated in State Economic Development Article, § 4-701.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of Finance or designee.

para.heading: Qualifying residing artist.
para.text: "Qualifying residing artist" has the meaning stated in Article 83A, § 4-701 of the Maryland Code.

para.heading: Exemption granted.
para.text: Subject to the requirements of this section, the gross receipts from any admissions or amusement charge levied by a qualifying residing artist or arts and entertainment enterprise in an arts and entertainment district are exempt from the tax imposed by this subtitle.
To be eligible for the exemption, the qualifying residing artist or arts and entertainment enterprise must register with the Director of Finance.
The registration shall be on the form and contain the information that the Director requires.

para.heading: Term of exemption.
para.text: An exemption under this section applies only for 10 years from the date on which the qualifying residing artist or arts and entertainment enterprise registers with the Director.

para.heading: Administration.
para.text: The Director may:
subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, adopt rules and regulations to implement the provisions of this section; and
delegate powers, duties, or functions in connection with the administration of this section to any employee of the City.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: "Simulated slot machine" defined.
para.text: In this section, "simulated slot machine" has the meaning stated in City Code Article 15 {"Licensing and Regulation"}, § 2-11 {"Definitions"}.

para.heading: Exemption granted.
para.text: The tax imposed by this subtitle does not apply to the gross receipts from a simulated slot machine that is licensed and registered as required by City Code Article 15 {"Licensing and Regulation"}, Subtitle 2 {"Amusements"}, Part 3 {"Amusement Devices"}.

annotations.annotation: This section was added by Ordinance 10-337. Section 4 of Ord. 10-337, provides that the Ordinance “takes effect on January 1, 2011, or, if later, on the 60th day after notice is given to the State Comptroller” of the enactment of this amendment to the City Admissions and Amusement Tax.
This subtitle was enacted by Ordinance 10-343, effective July 25, 2010, with a 3-year “sunset” provision. Subsequently, Ordinance 12-045 repealed the “sunset”.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Beverage" means, except as specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, any of the following:
any beer, ale, or other malt beverage;
any distilled spirits;
any wine, wine cooler, or other wine product;
any fruit juice with less than 10% natural fruit juice content;
any ready-to-drink tea;
any soda water, carbonated water, natural or artificial mineral water, or natural or spring water; and
any soft drink, including:
cola, ginger ale, root beer, or sarsparilla; or
any other carbonated or uncarbonated beverage commonly known as a "soft drink".

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Beverage" does not include:
any dairy products;
any nondairy, milk-substitute products, such as soy milk, hazelnut or other nut milk, rice or other grain milk, and the like;
any beverage containing at least 10% natural fruit juices; or
any beverage in a container of 2 liters or larger.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Dealer" means any person who engages in the retail sale of beverages subject to this subtitle.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Dealer" includes:
any business that permits on-premises consumption of beverages;
any distributor engaged in casual retail sales of beverages;
any operator of a vending machine from which beverages are sold; and
any individual outlet in the City of a multiple-outlet retail chain store.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of Finance or a designee of the Director of Finance.

para.heading: Distributor.
para.text: "Distributor" means:
any person who supplies non-reusable beverage containers to a dealer in the City;
any person who supplies and services vending machines in the City with non-reusable beverage containers; and
any multiple-outlet retail chain store that supplies non-reusable beverage containers to its individual outlets in the City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Non-reusable beverage container" means any individual, separate, and sealed glass, metal, or plastic bottle, can, jar, or carton that:
contains a beverage; and
is not ordinarily collected from consumers for refilling with a beverage.

para.heading: When not considered reusable.
para.text: A beverage container is not considered reusable if:
it is physically incapable of reuse; or
it is the type for which:
no deposit is required to be paid by the consumer; and
no refund is payable to the consumer by the dealer.
"Supply" means to provide, furnish, deliver, distribute, or transmit.

For purposes of this subtitle, the act of supplying non-reusable beverage containers to a dealer operating in the City is completed, and tax liability accrues, on receipt of the products by the dealer in the City.

section.heading: Tax imposed.
section.text: A tax is imposed on every distributor who supplies to a dealer operating in the City any non-reusable beverage containers.

section.heading: Amount of tax.
section.text: The amount of the tax imposed is 5¢ per non-reusable beverage container.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The tax imposed by this subtitle:
is due when the dealer receives the non-reusable beverage containers; and
must be paid on or before the 25th day of the month following the month in which the dealer received the non-reusable beverage container.
The distributor must remit the tax to the Director of Finance, together with a monthly report of all non-reusable beverage containers that the distributor supplied to dealers operating in the City.
The report must be in a form the Director approves.

para.heading: Dealer liable absent certification.
para.text: If any dealer transports non-reusable beverage containers into the City or causes non-reusable beverage containers to be transported into the City, the dealer is liable for the payment of the tax imposed by this subtitle, together with all applicable interest and penalties, unless the dealer obtains from the supplier of the products a written certification that the supplier is liable for and is paying the tax.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: The certification must be in a form the Director approves.

section.heading: Records.
section.text: Every distributor and every dealer must:

para.text: keep complete and accurate records of all transactions involving non-reusable beverage containers, as necessary or otherwise required by the Director to determine whether all taxes due under this subtitle have been paid; and
make these records available, at all times during business hours, for inspection and audit by the Director.

section.heading: Interest and civil penalties.
section.text: If a distributor fails to pay the tax imposed by this subtitle when due, the distributor must pay the Director, in addition to the tax due:

para.text: interest at the rate of 1% for each month or fraction of a month that the tax is overdue; and
a penalty of 10% of the amount of the tax due.

para.heading: Director to obtain information.
para.text: If any person fails to make the report and remit the tax when due and fails to keep suitable records as required under this subtitle, the Director of Finance may attempt to obtain other available information on which to base an estimate of the tax due.

para.heading: Director to estimate tax.
para.text: As soon as the Director obtains this information, the Director may proceed to determine the tax due and assess that tax, plus interest and penalties, against the person liable for the tax.
The Director may then notify the person by mail, sent to that person's last known address, of the total amount of the tax, interest, and penalties.
The total amount is payable within 10 days from the date of this notice.

section.heading: Closing or sale of business.
section.text: If a person required to pay a tax under this subtitle sells his, her, or its business or otherwise ceases to do business:

para.text: any tax payable under this subtitle becomes immediately due and payable; and
within 3 days of the sale or other cessation of business, that person must submit the required report and remit the total amount of the tax due.

section.heading: Lien on property.
section.text: The tax, interest, and penalties imposed by this subtitle are a lien on the property of any person liable for their payment.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director may adopt rules and regulations as necessary or appropriate to:

para.text: govern the payment, collection, and accounting of the tax imposed by this subtitle;
define any terms used in connection with the imposition and collection of the tax imposed under this subtitle;
provide for the credit of any tax paid on returned products;
provide for the refund of any tax, interest, or penalty erroneously or illegally paid; and
otherwise administer, enforce, and carry out this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Gross amounts of money.
para.text: "Gross amounts of money" means the total gross payments of any kind or character (including cash, credit, property, and services), whether received in money or otherwise, without any deduction for charges or other amounts for any services necessary to complete the transaction.

para.heading: Hotel.
para.text: "Hotel" means a building containing sleeping accommodations for more than 5 persons and open to the transient public.

para.heading: Owners or operators of hotels.
para.text: "Owners or operators of hotels" means any person:
possessing or having an ownership interest in a hotel;
engaged in the business of operating a hotel; or
receiving any consideration for the rental of a hotel room for sleeping accommodations, including, without limitation, any broker, service provider, or other intermediary:
with which a hotel has contracted to arrange for the rental of a hotel room for sleeping accommodations; or
that has acquired any hotel room for subsequent rental from the hotel for sleeping accommodations.

para.heading: Short-term residential rental (and related terms).
para.text: "Short-term residential rental" and related terms (such as "booking transaction", "dwelling unit", "host", "hosting platform", and "transient guest") have the respective meanings stated in City Code Article 15, Subtitle 48 {"Short-Term Residential Rentals"}.

para.heading: Transient guest or tenant.
para.text: "Transient guest or tenant" means a person or persons renting, using, or occupying a room or rooms for fewer than 90 consecutive days:
in a hotel for sleeping accommodations; or
in a dwelling unit for a short-term residential rental.

section.heading: Tax imposed.
section.text: A tax of 9.5%, to be paid and collected as provided in this subtitle, is levied and imposed on all gross amounts of money that are:

para.text: paid to the owners or operators of hotels in the City by transient guests or tenants for renting, using, or occupying a room or rooms for sleeping accommodations;
paid to hosting platforms by transient guests for booking or otherwise facilitating short-term residential rentals; or
paid to hosts by transient guests for providing short-term residential rentals.

para.heading: Tax to be collected and remitted.
para.text: Every person, firm, association, or corporation subject to the tax imposed by § 21-2 {"Tax imposed"} of this subtitle:
shall collect the tax levied and imposed by this subtitle from the persons paying the rental or other charges for the use or occupancy of any room or rooms for sleeping accommodations; and
shall pay the tax to the Director of Finance on or before the 25th day of each month.

para.heading: Forms.
para.text: At the same time that any such payment is made to the Director of Finance, the party making such payment shall file with the Director of Finance a statement, on such forms as may be prescribed by the Director of Finance, showing the amount of taxes collected during the preceding period, and setting forth such other data and information as may be required by the Director of Finance.

Any person, firm, association, or corporation that refuses or fails to collect the taxes imposed by this subtitle, or to make a proper return when due, or to pay the taxes collected over to the Director of Finance when due, is liable for and must pay to the Director, in addition to the tax due:
interest on the amount of tax due at the rate of 1% for each month or part of a month that the tax is overdue; and
a penalty of:
if the tax is 30 to 59 days past due, 30% of the amount due;
if the tax is 60 to 89 days past due, 60% of the amount due; and
if the tax is 90 days or more past due, 100% of the amount due.
The penalty imposed by paragraph (1)(ii) of this subsection applies to all unpaid taxes regardless of the original date on which the unpaid taxes first became due.

para.heading: Collection.
para.text: This interest and penalty shall be collected as a part of the tax itself.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Whenever any person erroneously, illegally, or unconstitutionally has paid the tax imposed by this subtitle, or whenever any person has paid the tax imposed by this subtitle in connection with a room or rooms in a hotel which such person has rented, used, or occupied for a period of 90 consecutive days or more, the Director of Finance shall refund the amount of such tax so paid upon receipt by him of a properly executed application stating good and sufficient grounds for any such refund.

para.heading: Application.
para.text: Any such application:
must be filed within 3 years from the date when the tax is paid;
must contain such information and be in such form as may be required or approved by the Director of Finance; and
must be signed by both the persons having paid the tax and the proper officer or officers of the particular hotel involved.

Whenever any person, firm, association, or corporation owning or operating any hotel business in Baltimore City shall sell, transfer, convey, or assign any such hotel business, the purchaser, transferee, or assignee thereof shall, at least 10 days before taking possession or control of such hotel business or paying therefor, notify the Director of Finance by registered mail of the proposed sale, transfer, conveyance, or assignment and of the price, terms, and conditions thereof.
The said notice shall be given to the Director of Finance:
whether or not the vendor, transferor, or assignor has represented to or informed the purchaser, transferee, or assignee that it owes any tax under the terms and provisions hereof; and
whether or not the purchaser, transferee, or assignee has knowledge that such taxes are in fact owing.

para.heading: Tax claim lien on purchase payment.

para.text: Whenever the purchaser, transferee, or assignee shall fail to give the said notice to the Director of Finance, as required by the terms and provisions hereof, or whenever the Director of Finance shall inform the purchaser, transferee, or assignee that a possible claim for such tax exists, any sums of money, property, or choses in action, or other consideration which the purchaser, transferee, or assignee is obligated to pay or transfer to the vendor, transferor, or assignor shall be subject to a first priority, right, and lien for said taxes theretofore or thereafter determined to be due from the vendor, transferor, or assignor to the City.

The purchaser, transferee, or assignee is forbidden to pay or transfer to the vendor, transferor, or assignor any of the aforementioned sums of money, property, or choses in action to the extent of the amount of the City's claim for unpaid taxes due under the terms and provisions hereof.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: For failure to comply with the terms and provisions of this section, the purchaser, transferee, or assignee:

shall be personally liable for the payment to the City of said taxes theretofore or thereafter determined to be due to the City from the vendor, transferor, or assignor, in the same manner and to the same extent as the vendor, transferor, or assignor; and
in addition thereto shall also be subject to the criminal penalties set forth in § 21-10.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance is hereby authorized to adopt or promulgate such rules and regulations as he may deem necessary or proper:
pertaining to the payment, collection, and accounting of the taxes levied and imposed by this subtitle; or
in connection with the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this subtitle.

para.heading: Additional powers of Director of Finance.
para.text: In addition to the powers granted to the Director of Finance in connection with the collection of the tax imposed by this subtitle, he is hereby authorized and empowered:
to compromise disputed claims in connection with the tax imposed by this subtitle and, for good and sufficient causes shown, to remit interest and penalties;

to delegate any of his powers, duties, and functions in connection with the collection of the tax imposed by this subtitle and the enforcement of the provisions relating thereto to the City Collector or any other agent, representative, or employee of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore; and
to extend for good cause shown the time for filing any return required to be filed under this subtitle and for such period of time as he may deem reasonable.
