section.heading: Criminal penalties.
section.text: The willful refusal on the part of any person, firm, association, or corporation to collect the said taxes, file proper returns when due, or pay the taxes collected by him or it over to the Director of Finance when due, as required by this subtitle or by regulations of the Director of Finance adopted pursuant hereto, or the filing of a return known to be false or incomplete, shall be a misdemeanor, and any person, firm, association, or corporation convicted thereof shall be subject to a fine of not more than $500 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months, or to both fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the Court.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the City Director of Finance.
"Facilitator" means a business entity that makes parking spaces in the City available for use by a person through an online, mobile, or other third-party booking platform:
for a certain amount of time; and
for a fee.
"Garage" means any structure or part of a structure for the parking of 3 or more motor vehicles in exchange for a fee or other consideration.
"Motor vehicle" means:
any self-propelled vehicle; and
any other vehicle required to be registered under the laws of this State or of any other state.
"Operator" means any person who controls, conducts, or operates a parking lot or garage.

"Parking" means any parking, storing, housing, or keeping of a motor vehicle, whether self-service, valet-service, long-term, short-term, ticketed metered, through coordination with a facilitator, for special events only, or otherwise.
"Parking lot" means any outdoor area or space for the parking of 3 or more motor vehicles in exchange for a fee or other consideration.
"Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this subtitle "person" also includes a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.
"Transaction" means the parking of a motor vehicle on a parking lot or in a garage in exchange for a fee or other consideration.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A tax is levied and imposed on the privilege of parking a motor vehicle on any parking lot or in any garage in the City in exchange for a fee or other consideration paid by the parker or by another on the parker's behalf.

para.heading: Ultimate liability.
para.text: The ultimate liability for payment of the tax is on the person who seeks the privilege of occupying a space on a parking lot or in a garage.

For all parking, whether on an hourly, daily, weekly, monthly, or longer basis, the tax is 20% of any fee or other consideration received, directly or indirectly, by the operator of the parking lot or garage or the facilitator, for or in connection with that parking.

para.heading: Moratorium on increase.
para.text: Through the fiscal year ending June 30, 2020, the rate of the tax imposed under this subtitle may not be modified to exceed the rate in effect for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2014.

para.heading: Exemption for residence parking.
para.text: The tax imposed by this subtitle does not apply to residential parking by:

the tenant of a single-family dwelling, multi-family dwelling, or apartment dwelling, if the parking is provided for in the lease or in a separate agreement between the landlord and the tenant, whether the parking fee or other consideration is paid to the landlord or to the operator of the parking lot or garage; or

the owner or occupant of a condominium unit, if the parking is provided for in an agreement between the condominium association and the owner or occupant, whether the parking fee or other consideration is paid to the condominium association or to the operator of the parking lot or garage.

para.heading: Publicly owned meters.
para.text: The tax imposed by this subtitle does not apply to publicly owned metered parking spaces.

para.heading: Reduction for nonprofits.
para.text: Nonprofit parking lot operators whose monthly parking fee is less than or equal to the monthly parking tax may apply to the Board of Estimates for a reduction of their tax burden.

(i) Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the operator of the parking lot or garage or the facilitator, must collect the tax imposed by this subtitle from the person seeking the privilege of parking.

The operator or the facilitator, must collect the tax at the same time that the operator or the facilitator collects any fee or other consideration charged for parking, whether that fee or other consideration is charged on an hourly, daily, weekly, monthly, or other basis.

para.heading: Remittance to Director.
para.text: The tax imposed by this subtitle must be remitted to the Director on or before the 25th day of the month following the month in which the transaction occurred.
Each remittance must be accompanied by a report of all transactions for the month.
The report must:
be in the form the Director requires;
identify, for each parking lot and garage, its name, address, account number, capacity, parking fees or rate schedule, and number and type of transactions; and
contain any other information the Director requires.

section.heading: Interest and civil penalties.
section.text: If an operator fails to remit the tax imposed by this subtitle when due, the operator must pay the Director, in addition to the tax due:

para.text: interest at the rate of 1% for each month or fraction of a month that the tax is overdue; and
a penalty of 10% of the amount of the tax due.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Every operator of a parking lot or garage must:
keep complete and accurate records of all motor vehicles parked on an hourly, daily, weekly, monthly, or other basis, together with the amount of tax collected from all transactions;
keep all claim checks and other pertinent records as necessary to determine the amount of tax due; and
make these records available, at all times, during business hours, for inspection and audit by the Director of Finance or other authorized agent, employee, or representative of the City.
Within 120 days after the end of an operator's fiscal year, the operator must file a financial report for that fiscal year with the City Auditor and the Director of Finance.
The report must be:
prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, consistently applied; and
certified by a public accountant.
The report must include:
balance sheets;
statements of operation; and
statements of changes in financial position and owners' equity.

If the operator is required by its lenders or investors to obtain an audited and certified annual report. the operator must furnish a copy of that report to the City Auditor and the Director of Finance within 30 days of its receipt by the operator.

para.heading: Setting rate on failure to comply.
para.text: If any operator fails to keep records from which the tax imposed by this subtitle can be accurately computed, the Director of Finance may compute the amount of tax due by using a factor developed by surveying other operators of a similar type, or otherwise. The Director's computation is prima facie correct.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance may adopt rules and regulations as necessary or appropriate to:

para.text: govern the payment, collection, and accounting of the tax imposed by this subtitle;
define any terms used in connection with the imposition and collection of the tax;
provide for the compromise of disputed claims and, for good and sufficient cause shown, the waiver of interest and penalties;
provide for the refund of any tax, interest, or penalty erroneously or illegally paid; and
otherwise administer, enforce, and carry out this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: Authorized.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, the Director of Finance may delegate any of his or her powers, duties, and functions under this subtitle to:
any agent, representative, or employee of the Department of Finance;
any other agency or unit of City government; or
the Baltimore City Parking Authority.
A delegation under this section must be made in writing.
For a delegation under subsection (a)(2) or (3) of this section, a copy of the writing must be filed with the Board of Estimates before it becomes effective.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: Rules and regulations under this subtitle may only be adopted by the Director of Finance.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct.
section.text: The operator of a parking lot or garage may not:

para.text: fail, neglect, or refuse to collect or remit the tax imposed by this subtitle;
make any incomplete, false, or fraudulent return;
fail to keep complete and accurate records;
refuse to permit the Director or authorized agent, employee, or representative to inspect and audit the operator's records; or
fail to fully comply with any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle.

section.heading: Criminal penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 6 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

section.heading: Scope of subtitle.
section.text: It is hereby declared that nothing contained in this subtitle shall be deemed or held to apply to any pole bearing a public lamp or lamp used to light any street, lane, or alley, or other public place in the City.

section.heading: Identification and report.
section.text: All persons and corporations having, using, or maintaining any telegraph, telephone, electric light, or other poles in any of the streets, lanes, or alleys of the City of Baltimore, shall:

para.text: annually, between May 15 and June 1, in each and every year, file with the Director of Transportation a list of all poles so used, possessed, or maintained by them, giving the accurate locations of each pole; and
shall also have stamped, painted, or printed, in legible characters, their name as owner upon each of such poles.

para.heading: Annual fee required.
para.text: Annually in the 1st week of January, all persons or corporations shall pay to the Director of Finance a fee of $50 for each and every telephone, electric light, or other pole used, possessed, or maintained by them in any of the streets, lanes, or alleys of the City of Baltimore, except trolley poles used exclusively for stringing thereon wires for use in the propulsion, by electricity, of street passenger cars.

para.heading: Metal plates and receipts.
para.text: Upon receiving the above fee in January, 1948, and subsequent years:

the Director of Finance shall deliver to the person or corporation paying the same a permanent metal plate, with a plain and conspicuous number thereon, to be provided in the manner prescribed in § 23-4, only for such poles for which permanent metal plates have not been issued prior thereto;
the Director of Finance shall also keep a record of the name of the person or corporation to whom the license is issued, and the number of poles for which license fees are paid; and

he shall also deliver to such person or corporation a certificate that such person or corporation has paid the required license fee for that year, on the specified number of poles, and that permanent metal plates of the given numbers have been issued therefor.

para.heading: Plates to be attached.
para.text: Such person or corporation shall then have 1 of such permanent metal plates securely fastened in some conspicuous place upon each of the poles used, possessed, or maintained by it or him.

para.heading: Director to obtain.
para.text: It shall be the duty of the Director of Finance on or before January 1, 1926, to purchase a sufficient number of permanent metal plates, numbered with plain conspicuous numbers, beginning with a given number for each person or corporation required to license its poles as hereinafter provided, and so on progressively, and on or before January 1, 1927, and subsequent years, to purchase a sufficient number of permanent metal plates, beginning with the number next succeeding that last issued to any person or corporation, or with a given number, if the person or corporation has had no licensed poles during 1926 or subsequent years, said permanent metal plates to be furnished as prescribed in § 23-3 to the persons or corporations using, possessing, or maintaining telegraph, telephone, electric light, or other poles other than trolley poles used exclusively for stringing wires thereon for use in the propulsion, by electricity, of street passenger cars.

para.heading: Specifications.
para.text: The Director of Finance shall cause such permanent metal plates to display the initials or some other symbol denoting the person or corporation to which they are issued; the said plates to be of suitable size and description, in the discretion of the Director of Finance and to be paid for out of the appropriation for general licenses.

para.heading: Transfer to replacement pole.
para.text: Provided that in the event any licensee shall replace any pole with another, he may transfer the license to such other pole.

para.heading: Replacement plates.
para.text: And provided, further, that the Director of Finance may purchase and furnish without cost to the licensee, duplicate metal plates whenever in his judgment those in use have become illegible through natural wear and tear.

section.heading: Removal of noncomplying poles.
section.text: All telegraph, telephone, electric light, and other poles in any of the streets, lanes, and alleys of the City (except trolley poles used exclusively for wires used in the propulsion of street passenger cars):

para.text: which have not been included in any list filed in accordance with § 23-2 with the Director of Transportation; or
upon which the name of the owner is not legibly painted, printed, or stamped; or
upon which the license fee has not been paid; or
on which the prescribed tin plate is not securely fastened in some conspicuous place,

on or before June 15 in any year, shall be forthwith removed by its owner and, in default thereof, may be cut or taken down and removed from the streets by the Director of Transportation, in addition to the owner incurring the penalties provided in § 23-7 of this subtitle.

section.heading: Criminal penalties.
section.text: Any person or persons, or corporation using, possessing, or maintaining any telegraph, telephone, electric light, or other poles in any of the streets, lanes, and alleys of the City:

para.text: who fails to file a list of these poles with the Director of Transportation, as prescribed in § 23-2 of this subtitle;
who fails to have stamped, printed, or painted in legible characters, the owner's name on each of these poles, as prescribed in§ 23-2 of this subtitle;
who, as required by § 23-3 of this subtitle:
fails to pay the prescribed fee for each pole; or
fails to have the prescribed tin plate securely fastened in some conspicuous place

by June 15 of each and every year, shall forfeit and pay a fine of $10 for each pole for which he, they, or it are so in default; this fine to be collected as other fines and penalties for the violation of City ordinances are collected.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Finance Director; Director.
para.text: "Finance Director" or "Director" means the Director of Finance or a designee of the Director of Finance.

para.heading: Operator.
para.text: "Operator" means any person who owns, controls, operates, or manages a passenger-for-hire service.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Passenger-for-hire service" means any taxicab service, limousine service, sedan service, or transportation network service that, for remuneration, transports passengers within or from Baltimore City.

para.heading: Supplemental definitions.
para.text: "Taxicab service", "limousine service","sedan service", "transportation network service", and "remuneration" have the meanings stated in the State Public Utilities Article § 10-101.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Person" does not include a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

section.heading: Tax imposed.
section.text: An excise tax is levied and imposed on every person who operates a passenger-for-hire service within or from Baltimore City.

section.heading: Amount of tax.
section.text: The amount of the tax imposed is 25¢ for each trip:

para.text: between points within Baltimore City; or
from a point within Baltimore City to a point outside Baltimore City.

section.heading: Exceptions.
section.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

para.text: transportation services operated by or under contract with:
a unit of federal, state, or local government; or
a nonprofit entity that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) or § 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code;

an ambulance that is classified as a Class C (funeral and ambulance) vehicle under State Transportation Article § 13-914, is owned or operated by a licensed ambulance service or by a volunteer fire company or rescue squad, and is being used to transport an individual who is sick, injured, wounded, or otherwise incapacitated; or

a funeral limousine, coach, service wagon, or similar vehicle that is classified as a Class C (funeral and ambulance) vehicle under State Transportation Article § 13-914, is owned or operated by a licensed funeral establishment, funeral director, or mortician, and is being used to transport individuals to, from, or during a funeral service.

para.heading: Remittance.
para.text: For a taxicab service, limousine service, or sedan service, the operator of that service must remit the tax imposed by this subtitle to the Finance Director on or before the 25th day of the month following the month in which the service was provided.
Each remittance must be accompanied by a report of all service transactions for the month.
The report must be in the form and contain the information that the Finance Director requires.

para.heading: Transportation network services.
para.text: For a transportation network service, the tax imposed by this subtitle must be collected and remitted to the State Comptroller in accordance with State Public Utilities Article § 10-406(g).

section.heading: Interest and civil penalties.
section.text: If the operator fails to remit the tax imposed by this subtitle when due, the operator must pay the Finance Director, in addition to the tax due:

para.text: interest at the rate of 1% for each month or fraction of a month that the tax is overdue; and
a penalty of 10% of the amount of the tax due.

section.heading: Records.
section.text: Every operator must:

para.text: keep and maintain complete and accurate records of all passenger-for-hire services, as necessary or otherwise required by the Finance Director; and
make these records available, at all times during business hours, for inspection and audit by the Director of Finance or other authorized agent, employee, or representative of the City.

para.heading: Director to obtain information.
para.text: If any operator fails to make the report, remit the tax due, or keep records as required by this subtitle, the Finance Director may attempt to obtain other available information on which to base an estimate of the tax due.

para.heading: Director to estimate tax.
para.text: As soon as the Director obtains this information, the Director may proceed to determine the tax due and assess that tax, plus interest and penalties, against the operator.
The Director may then notify the operator by mail, sent to that operator's last known address, of the total amount of the tax, interest, and penalties.
The total amount is payable within 10 days from the date of this notice.

section.heading: Sale or closing of business.
section.text: If an operator sells its business or otherwise ceases to do business:

para.text: any tax payable under this subtitle becomes immediately due and payable; and
within 3 days of the sale or other cessation of business, that operator must submit the required report and remit the total amount of the tax due.

section.heading: Lien on property.
section.text: The tax, interest, and penalties imposed by this subtitle are a lien on the property of any person liable for their payment.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance may adopt rules and regulations as necessary or appropriate to:
govern the payment, collection, and accounting of the tax imposed by this subtitle;
define any terms used in connection with the imposition and collection of the tax imposed by this subtitle;
provide for the compromise of disputed claims and, for good and sufficient cause shown, the waiver of interest and penalties;
provide for the refund of any tax, interest, or penalty erroneously or illegally paid; and
otherwise administer, enforce, and carry out this subtitle.

para.heading: Taxicab service operating groups or associations.
para.text: The rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle may include standards and procedures by which an operating group or association, as described in COMAR 20.90.02.08 {"Operating Associations"}, may remit the taxes, submit the reports, and maintain the records otherwise required by this subtitle for and on behalf of taxicab service operators associated with that operating group or association.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this Part 1, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Place of primary use.
para.text: "Place of primary use" has the meaning stated in the Sourcing Act.

para.heading: Sourcing Act.
para.text: "Sourcing Act" means the federal Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Act, 4 U.S.C. §§ 116 through 126 (Pub.L. 106-252).

para.heading: Telecommunications line.
para.text: "Telecommunications line" means a wired or wireless connection, identifiable by a unique telephone number, to an exchange, wireless, or other telecommunications service.
"Wireless service" means any mobile telecommunications service, as that term is used in the Sourcing Act.
"Wireless service" includes any:
cellular telephone service;
personal communication service ("PSC");
commercial mobile radio service ("CMRS"); or
global system for mobile communications ("GSM").

section.heading: Tax imposed.
section.text: A tax is levied and imposed on each person who leases, licenses, or sells a telecommunications line to any customer:

para.text: for wired service, whose billing address or fixed service address is in the City; or
for wireless service, whose place of primary use is in the City.

section.heading: Rate of tax.
section.text: The rate of the tax imposed by this Part 1 is:

para.text: $0.40 per month or part of a month for each Centrex local exchange access line or trunk line; and
$4.00 per month or part of a month for every other telecommunications line, whether a residence, business, PBX local exchange, or other wired or wireless telecommunications line.

Section 3. And be it further ordained, That the tax rates established in ... this Ordinance, as applied to members of the Maryland Hospital Association and members of the Maryland Independent College and University Association, may not be increased as long as the Memorandum of Understanding between the City and these Associations is in effect and the Associations are in compliance with the terms and conditions of the Memorandum of Understanding.

section.heading: Exemptions.
section.text: The tax imposed by this Part 1 does not apply to a telecommunications line furnished to a telecommunications "lifeline service" customer, as defined by the rules of the Federal Communications Commission and the State Public Service Commission.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Each person subject to the tax imposed by this Part I must remit the tax to the Director of Finance, together with a monthly report, on or before the 25th day of the month following the month for which the tax is due.

para.heading: Report.
para.text: The report must be made under oath, in the form that the Director of Finance requires.

section.heading: Records.
section.text: Every person who leases, licenses, or sells telecommunications lines subject to the tax imposed by the Part 1 must:

para.text: keep complete and accurate records of all transactions involving those telecommunications lines, as necessary or otherwise required by the Director of Finance to determine whether taxes due under this Part 1 have been paid; and
make these records available, at all times during business hours, for inspection and audit by authorized representatives of the City.

section.heading: Interest and civil penalties.
section.text: If a person fails to pay the tax imposed by this Part 1 when due, the person must pay to the Director of Finance, in addition to the tax due:

para.text: interest at the rate of 1% for each month or part of a month that the tax is overdue; and
a penalty of 10% of the amount of the tax due.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance may adopt rules and regulations as necessary or appropriate:

para.text: to insure the payment, collection, and accounting of the tax imposed by this Part 1; and
to define or further define any terms used in this Part 1.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this Part 1or of any rule or regulation adopted under this Part 1, or who makes any false statement or improper return, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this Part 2, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of Finance or the Director's designee.

para.heading: Energy.
para.text: "Energy" means artificial or natural gas, electricity, coal, fuel oil, liquefied petroleum gas, or steam delivered for consumption in Baltimore City.
"Revenue" means the total amount billed for the sale, delivery, or distribution of energy to users.
"Revenue" includes, by way of description and not limitation, the amount billed for energy or fuel cost adjustments, delivery or system charges, and service charges.

"Revenue" does not include finance charges, late payment charges, other government taxes or surcharges, the tax imposed by this Part, charges associated with the initial hook-up or re-connection to the vendor's system.

para.heading: User.
para.text: "User" includes any person that receives delivery of energy, other than for resale or for conversion into another form of energy subject to the tax imposed by this Part 2.

para.heading: Vendor.
para.text: "Vendor" means any person that delivers energy subject to the tax imposed by this Part 2 directly to a user.

section.heading: Tax imposed.
section.text: There is levied and imposed a tax on energy delivered through pipes, wires, or conduits to all users in the City other than those exempted by this Part.

section.heading: Exemptions.
section.text: The tax imposed by this Part 2 does not apply to energy delivered to any of the following:

para.text: the United States and its agencies, unless subject to local tax under federal law;
the State of Maryland and its agencies; and
the City of Baltimore and its agencies.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: For each fiscal year, the rates of the tax will be established as provided in this section.

para.heading: Certification of revenues and units.
para.text: On or before the preceding February 1, each person that sells, distributes, or delivers energy shall certify to the Director, on the forms and in the manner required by the Director:

the aggregate units of energy (e.g., kWhs, therms, gallons, pounds, tons) supplied and delivered during the prior calendar year directly to all persons, governmental entities, instrumentalities, and units, and others, whether subject to or exempt from the tax imposed by this Part 2;
the aggregate revenues derived from the sale, distribution, or delivery of that energy; and
a breakdown of these aggregate units and revenues by class of user, as defined and prescribed by the Director.
For each class of energy and each class of user, the Director shall compute a base year tax rate for Fiscal Year 2005 by:
multiplying the sum of the revenues from each class of user for each class of energy by 0.08; and
then dividing that product by the sum of the units of each class of energy delivered to the class of users.

For Fiscal Year 2011 and each subsequent fiscal year, the base year tax rate shall be the amount computed under paragraph (1) of this subsection, as adjusted under subsection (d) of this section, multiplied by 1.15%.

para.heading: Annual adjustments.
para.text: For Fiscal Year 2006 and each subsequent fiscal year, these tax rates shall be adjusted by the percentage change in the Baltimore-Columbia-Towson Consumer Price Index, as reported by the United States Department of Labor, comparing December of the preceding calendar year to the December of the next preceding calendar year.

para.heading: Percentage to be paid.
para.text: For each of the following classes of users, the user is required to pay the following percentage of that year's tax rate:
residential energy users subject to residential schedules on file with the Public Service Commission of Maryland –
– Fiscal Year 2005 and subsequent, 25%.

direct users of energy in manufacturing, assembling, processing, or refining operations that are exempt from the Maryland State Retail Sales and Use Tax, but not including uses of energy for the following (for which the full tax shall be paid, as stated in paragraph(4) of this subsection):
maintaining, servicing, or repairing;
testing finished products;
providing for the comfort or health of employees;
operating administrative or commercial facilities, such as offices, sales or display rooms, retail outlets, and storage facilities (including refrigerated storage facilities); or

any other operations that the State Comptroller incorporates from time to time in the regulations governing the administration of the Maryland State Retail Sales and Use Tax, as those inclusions relate to manufacturing, assembling, processing, or refining –
– Fiscal Years 2005 and 2006, 25%; Fiscal Year 2007 and subsequent, 0%.

any nonprofit hospital, religious, charitable, or educational institution or organization, or any in-patient medical care or nursing facility licensed by the State or City Health Departments, with respect to energy used in carrying on the work of the nonprofit institution or organization or the in-patient medical care or nursing facility –

– Fiscal Year 2005, 0%; Fiscal Years 2006 through 2010, 75%; Fiscal Year 2011 and subsequent, 87% of the commercial rate imposed on the users listed in subitems (A) through (E) of item (2) of this subsection.
all other users –
– Fiscal Year 2005 and subsequent, 100%.

If a person that sells, distributes, or delivers energy fails to provide the certification required by subsection (b) of this section, the Director may use any reasonable data to establish a proposed rate of taxation.
A determination made by the Director is presumed valid.
The rates computed by the Director shall be included in the proposed operating budget submitted by the Director to the Board of Estimates.
After the adoption of the operating budget, the Director shall certify to each vendor the rates of tax for the fiscal year as included in the adopted budget.

annotation.text: Subsections (c) and (e) of this section were amended by Ord. 10-300. Sections 3 and 4 of that Ordinance provide as follows

Section 3. And be it further ordained, That, notwithstanding the tax rates set by this Ordinance, the rate applicable to members of the Maryland Hospital Association and members of the Maryland Independent College and University Association may not exceed that agreed to in the Memorandum of Understanding between the City and these Associations, as long as the Memorandum of Understanding is in effect and the Associations are in compliance with its terms and conditions.

Section 4. And be it further ordained, That the tax rate set by this Ordinance for residential users may not be increased as long as the Memorandum of Understanding referred to in Section 3 of this Ordinance is in effect and the Associations are in compliance with its terms and conditions.

para.heading: Vendor to collect.
para.text: Each vendor shall itemize the tax on each bill and collect the tax from the user.

para.heading: Vendor's rights.
para.text: The vendor has the same rights against the user for collection of the tax as it has for collection of the energy bill.

section.heading: Remittance.
section.text: By the 25th day of the month, each vendor shall:

para.text: file a return with the Director, under oath and on a form provided by the Director; and
pay the amount of tax billed to a user for the preceding month.

section.heading: Refunds – Uncollectible accounts; tax erroneously paid.

para.text: If a vendor is unable to collect an account receivable for which the tax already has been remitted and the vendor has charged off that account as worthless, the vendor may deduct the amount of the tax from its monthly remittance, subject to the requirements of this subsection.
The vendor must:
before availing itself of this privilege, provide the Director with a written statement of its policies governing the determination of worthless accounts; and
as a condition of taking any deduction:
keep records of every worthless account for which the vendor has taken a deduction; and
make those records available to the Director, on request, for review or collection efforts.

para.heading: Tax paid erroneously, etc.
para.text: Whenever a tax imposed under this Part 2 has been erroneously, illegally, or unconstitutionally paid, the Director shall refund the tax if the application for refund:
is made within 3 years from the payment of the tax; and
states a proper ground for refund.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person that has paid the tax imposed under this Part 2 for any energy delivered to residential users or to combined residential and commercial users may apply annually to the Director for a refund of that portion of the taxes paid in excess of the applicable rate reasonably allocable to residential users only.
The application shall:
be signed by the applicant;
contain a sworn affidavit as to the truth and accuracy of the information set forth in it;
be filed not later than April 1 of each year; and
cover the preceding 12 months.
Any application not received by April 1 in any particular year may not be given consideration.
The Director may refund that portion of the taxes determined to have been paid in connection with energy delivered to residential users only.
Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director may adopt rules and regulations to assist in making that determination.
Any refund shall be made from a reserve fund created out of a portion of the tax receipts collected under this Part 2.
The reserve fund shall be in an amount estimated to be sufficient to pay the refunds authorized by this section.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Every vendor must:
keep complete and accurate records of all transactions, as necessary or otherwise required by the Director to determine whether taxes due under this Part 2 have been paid; and
make these records available, at all times during business hours, for inspection and audit by authorized representatives of the City.

para.heading: Failure to keep.
para.text: If a vendor fails to keep records from which the tax imposed by this Part 2 may be accurately computed, the Director may use criteria developed by surveying other taxpayers of the same type or otherwise, compute the amount of tax due, and this computation is presumed correct.

section.heading: Interest and civil penalties.
section.text: If a vendor fails to pay the tax imposed by this Part 2 when due, the vendor must pay to the Director, in addition to the tax due:

para.text: interest at the rate of 1% for each month or part of a month that the tax is overdue; and
a penalty of 10% of the amount of the tax due.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance may adopt rules and regulations as necessary or appropriate:

para.text: to insure the payment, collection, and accounting of the tax imposed by this Part 2; and
to define or further define any terms used in this Part 2.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this Part 2 or of any rule or regulation adopted under this Part 2, or who makes any false statement or improper return, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than$1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

annotation.text: Section 4 of Ord. 04-728 provides for the severability of the provisions enacted. Section 6 of that Ordinance provides for periodic reporting to the City Council, as follows

[O]n or before October 1, 2005, and October 1 of each 5th year following, the Director of Finance shall submit a report to the City Council on the revenues derived from and the effect of the tax established under this Ordinance during the preceding fiscal years.

section.heading: Fee imposed.
section.text: In accordance with State Public Safety Article § 1-311, an additional charge of $1 per month is levied and imposed on all current bills rendered for switched local exchange access service, wireless telephone service, or other 911-accessible service within Baltimore City.

section.heading: Application.
section.text: This charge:

para.text: is in addition to the 911 fee imposed by State Public Safety Article § 1-310; and
shall be applied to all current bills rendered for switched local exchange access service, wireless telephone service, or other 911-accessible service within Baltimore City.

annotation.text: This subtitle was enacted by Ord. 99-388, effective July 1, 1999. Section 3 of that Ordinance provides that the subtitle “shall remain in effect unless the Maryland General Assembly enacts a Statewide tax on tobacco products; if a Statewide tax on tobacco products becomes effective, this Ordinance is abrogated and of no further force and effect, with no further action required by the Mayor and City Council.”

After the enactment of Ord. 99-388, the General Assembly enacted Chapter 121, Laws of Maryland 1999. Section 1 of that Act increases the rate of the preexisting tax on cigarettes; Sections 2 and 3 of the Act impose a new tax on certain other tobacco products. Section 9, in turn, provides that Section 1 (the cigarette tax increase) becomes effective July 1, 1999; Section 8, on the other hand, provides that Sections 2 and 3 (the new Statewide tax on other tobacco products) only become effective July 1, 2000.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
"Cigar" means any cigar, cheroot, stogie, cigarillo, or other roll of tobacco that is wrapped in leaf tobacco or in any other substance that contains tobacco.
"Cigar" does not include a cigarette.

para.heading: Cigarette.
para.text: "Cigarette" has the meaning stated in § 12-101(b) of the State Tax-General Article.
"Dealer" means any person who engages in the retail sale of tobacco products subject to this subtitle.
"Dealer" includes:
any distributor engaged in casual retail sales of tobacco products;
any operator of a vending machine from which tobacco products are sold; and
individual outlets in the City of multiple-outlet retail chain stores.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of Finance or a designee of the Director of Finance.

para.heading: Distributor.
para.text: "Distributor" means:
any person who supplies tobacco products to a dealer;
any person who supplies vending machines with tobacco products; and
any multiple-outlet retail chain store that supplies tobacco products to its individual outlets.

para.heading: Pipe tobacco.
para.text: "Pipe tobacco" means any tobacco that, because of its appearance, type, packaging, or labeling, is suitable or intended to be smoked in a pipe.

para.heading: Smokeless tobacco.
para.text: "Smokeless tobacco" means any chewing tobacco, spit tobacco, snuff, or other finely cut, ground, powdered, or leaf tobacco that is:
intended to be placed in the oral cavity or nasal passage; or
otherwise not intended to be smoked.
"Supply" means to provide, furnish, deliver, distribute, or transmit.
For purposes of this subtitle, the act of supplying tobacco products to a dealer operating in the City is completed, and tax liability accrues, on receipt of the products by the dealer in the City.
"Tobacco product" means any:
cigar;
pipe tobacco; or
smokeless tobacco.
"Tobacco product" does not include a cigarette.

section.heading: Tax imposed.
section.text: A tax is imposed on every distributor who supplies to a dealer operating in the City any:

para.text: cigar;
pipe tobacco; or
smokeless tobacco.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The amount of the tax imposed is as specified in this section.

para.heading: Cigars.
para.text: For cigars, the tax is:

td.p: (1) for cigars weighing 3 pounds or less per 1,000:
(2) for cigars weighing more than 3 pounds per 1,000:

para.heading: Pipe tobacco.
para.text: For pipe tobacco, the tax is:

td.p: (1) for each package of 1.5 ounces or less:
(2)for each package of more than 1.5 ounces:
$0.36 per unit or fraction of a unit of 1.5 ounces

para.heading: Smokeless tobacco.
para.text: For smokeless tobacco, the tax is:

td.p: (1) for each package of 1.5 ounces or less:
(2) for each package of more than 1.5 ounces:
$0.36 per unit or fraction of a unit of 1.5 ounces

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The tax imposed by this subtitle:
is due when the dealer receives the tobacco product; and
must be paid on or before the 25th day of the month following the month in which the dealer received the product.
The distributor must remit the tax to the Director of Finance, together with a monthly report of all tobacco products that the distributor supplied to dealers operating in the City.
The report must:
be in a form the Director approves; and
identify the number of products supplied in each of the classifications specified in § 27-3 of this subtitle.

para.heading: Dealer liable absent certification.
para.text: If any dealer transports tobacco products into the City or causes tobacco products to be transported into the City, the dealer is liable for the payment of the tax imposed by this subtitle, together with all applicable interest and penalties, unless the dealer obtains from the supplier of the products a written certification that the supplier is liable for and is paying the tax.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: The certification must be in a form the Director approves.

section.heading: Records.
section.text: Every distributor and every dealer must:

para.text: keep complete and accurate records of all transactions involving tobacco products, as necessary or otherwise required by the Director to determine whether all taxes due under this subtitle have been paid; and
make these records available, at all times during business hours, for inspection and audit by the Director.

section.heading: Interest and civil penalties.
section.text: If a distributor fails to pay the tax imposed by this subtitle when due, the distributor must pay the Director, in addition to the tax due:

para.text: interest at the rate of 1% for each month or fraction of a month that the tax is overdue; and
a penalty of 10% of the amount of the tax due.

para.heading: Director to obtain information.
para.text: If any person fails to make the report and remit the tax when due and fails to keep suitable records as required under this subtitle, the Director of Finance may attempt to obtain other available information on which to base an estimate of the tax due.

para.heading: Director to estimate tax.
para.text: As soon as the Director obtains this information, the Director may proceed to determine the tax due and assess that tax, plus interest and penalties, against the person liable for the tax.
The Director may then notify the person by mail, sent to that person's last known address, of the total amount of the tax, interest, and penalties.
The total amount is payable within 10 days from the date of this notice.

section.heading: Closing or sale of business.
section.text: If a person required to pay a tax under this subtitle sells his, her, or its business or otherwise ceases to do business:

para.text: any tax payable under this subtitle becomes immediately due and payable; and
within 3 days of the sale or other cessation of business, that person must submit the required report and remit the total amount of the tax due.

section.heading: Lien on property.
section.text: The tax, interest, and penalties imposed by this subtitle are a lien on the property of any person liable for their payment.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, Director may adopt rules and regulations as necessary or appropriate to:

para.text: govern the payment, collection, and accounting of the tax imposed by this subtitle;
define any terms used in connection with the imposition and collection of the tax imposed under this subtitle;
provide for the credit of any tax paid on returned products;
provide for the refund of any tax, interest, or penalty erroneously or illegally paid; and
otherwise administer, enforce, and carry out this subtitle.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

container.heading: Sales or Use Tax on Controlled Dangerous Substances

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms shall mean or include:

para.heading: Assessment.
para.text: "Assessment" means any amount of tax that has been imposed under this subtitle, together with all interest charges and penalties added.

para.heading: Consignment.
para.text: "Consignment" means the placement or deposit of controlled dangerous substances in the actual or constructive custody of a person for the purpose of:
selling the consigned controlled dangerous substances; and
remitting the proceeds of such sales, or portions of proceeds, to the person making the placement or deposit or a designee.

para.heading: Controlled dangerous substance.
para.text: "Controlled dangerous substances" or "controlled substances" are those defined in Article 27, § 277 of the Maryland Code.

para.heading: Court.
para.text: "Court" means a court of law or court of equity or any judge thereof, and includes the District Court of Maryland for Baltimore City, Circuit Court for Baltimore City, Court of Special Appeals, and Court of Appeals.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of Finance for Baltimore City or a designee.

para.heading: Narcotics operation.
para.text: "Narcotics operation" means any kind of private business for the sale, purchase, possession, transfer, or consignment of controlled dangerous substances, which business is comprised or carried out by more than 1 such activity, whether for profit or for any other consideration including accommodation to another person.
"Notice" shall mean actual notice or notice through documents:
which shall be delivered at the dwelling or usual place of business of the taxpayer, if the address is known or readily obtainable, and to a person 18 years of age or older; or
which shall be sent by certified mail to the taxpayer's last known address.
Any period of time which is determined according to the provisions of this subtitle by the giving of notice shall commence to run from the date of mailing of such notice.
"Records" or "business records" means all records of any type or form and however recorded which relates to a narcotics operation, or transaction, or profit therefrom.

These terms include books of account, vouchers, documents, canceled checks, payrolls, correspondence, records of purchase(s) or sale(s), accounts payable, accounts receivable, and records of personnel, or agents, or consignees, customers, equipment, production or import activities, and other business papers.

"Sale" means any transaction of any nature, wholesale, retail, or otherwise, whereby possession of a controlled dangerous substance is or is to be transferred by any means whatsoever for any consideration past, present, or future.
Consideration may be in the form of money, services, or property, or by exchange or barter, or pursuant to consignment.
Sale also includes transfer by theft or gift.

para.heading: Taxpayer.
para.text: "Taxpayer" means any person upon whom a tax is assessed under this subtitle.

para.heading: Use, storage, or consumption.
para.text: "Use, storage, or consumption" means the exercise by any person of any right or power over controlled dangerous substances, or any keeping or retention within Baltimore City for any purpose of controlled dangerous substances sold either within or without Baltimore City.

section.heading: Tax imposed.
section.text: There is hereby levied and imposed a tax on each separate sale, or use, storage, or consumption of controlled dangerous substances within Baltimore City.

section.heading: Rate of tax.
section.text: The tax rate is 15% of the value in money of the controlled substance as evidenced by the actual money or money value consideration for its sale, or use, storage, or consumption or by its street value at or about the time of the taxable event.

section.heading: Exemptions.
section.text: This subtitle does not apply to sales, use, storage, or consumption by any person who registers under or complies with Article 27, § 281 of the Maryland Code, or any person who otherwise complies with that section of the Code. The burden of proof of an exemption is upon the person claiming it.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The tax shall be paid by the person who sells, stores, consumes, or steals the controlled dangerous substances subject to the tax.

para.heading: Taxable event.
para.text: The tax is payable for each separate taxable event and every person who is a party to the event is jointly and severally liable for the payment of the tax, but the tax is not duplicated when there is in fact only 1 transaction or event.

para.heading: Documentation of value.
para.text: If written records, receipts, or other evidence or information demonstrate that controlled substances have been sold, used, stored, or consumed by any person, the Director may use such information to establish the amount of and to collect tax under the provisions of this subtitle.
The tax shall be due upon the event of the sale, use, storage, or consumption of taxable controlled dangerous substances and is payable to the Director within 15 days following the taxable event.
Payment, or satisfaction, of the assessed tax shall be made by certified or cashier's check, money order or bank draft made payable to the Director.

para.heading: Receipts.
para.text: The Director shall, upon request, issue receipts for all sums collected pursuant to this subtitle.

section.heading: Interest and civil penalties.
section.text: All taxes upon controlled substances which are not paid within 15 days following the due date shall be overdue, and from and after that date they shall bear, until paid:

para.text: interest at the rate of 2.5% for each month and fraction thereof; and
penalty at the rate of 2.5% for each month and fraction thereof.

para.heading: Findings and declaration.
para.text: Because of the nature of the transactions involved in the illegal sale, use, storage, or consumption of controlled dangerous substances, the Mayor and City Council find and declare that the collection of the tax imposed by this subtitle on such transactions is in jeopardy and requires the immediate attachment of a lien therefor from the time the tax is payable, subject to the revisions and appeals procedure provided.

para.heading: Tax a lien.
para.text: The tax imposed under this subtitle, and all increases, interest, and penalties thereon shall be a lien upon all the property, real and/or personal, of any person liable to pay the same to the City from and after the time that the tax is due and payable as provided herein.

para.heading: Recordation.
para.text: Notice of such lien shall be filed by the Director with the Clerk of the Circuit Court for Baltimore City or the Clerk of the Circuit Court of the county in which the property may be located, who shall accurately and promptly record and index all such notices of lien by entering such lien in the judgment docket of the court, stating the name of the delinquent taxpayer, the amount of the lien and the date thereof.
The lien provided for in this section shall have the full force and effect of a lien of judgment.
Unless another date is specified by law, the lien arising at the date of nonpayment as in this section specified and provided for, shall continue with the same force and effect as a judgment lien.
Any such lien on personal property shall not be effective as against an innocent purchaser for value unless the personal property has been levied upon by an officer of a court.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The tax, as assessed by the Director, with any penalties included therein, shall be presumed to be valid and correctly determined and assessed, and the burden shall be upon the taxpayer to show its incorrectness or invalidity.

para.heading: Director's statement prima facie evidence.
para.text: Any statement filed by the Director with the clerk of court, or any other certificate by the Director of the amount of tax and penalties as determined or assessed by him, shall be admissible as evidence and shall establish prima facie the facts that are set forth therein.

When the tax is not timely paid, the Director shall give notice of assessment to each person deemed liable for the unpaid tax, and any penalty and interest due, stating the amount owed and demanding payment thereof, provided that the Director under reasonable standards, uniformly applied, determines that the giving of the notice and the collection of the amount due are practicable.
Failure to give or receive notice does not relieve a taxpayer of the obligation and liability for payment of any tax, interest, and penalty due.

para.heading: Limitations.
para.text: Notice of assessment and notice of lien under this subtitle shall be given not more than 3 years:
after the sale, use, storage, or consumption of the controlled substances;
after the seizure of records pursuant to an investigation of sales, use, storage, or consumption of such substances; or
after the disposition of criminal charges or arrest or indictment resulting from the sale, use, storage, or consumption of such substances,
whichever occurrence is latest in time.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any taxpayer may apply to the Director for refund of tax alleged to have been erroneously, illegally, or unconstitutionally paid.

para.heading: Application.
para.text: Application for refund must:
be made in writing;
be made within 1 year of the payment of the tax; and
state the reasons why the taxpayer believes a refund is due.

para.heading: Director to act promptly.
para.text: The Director:
shall act upon such application promptly; and
shall provide notice to the taxpayer of the action.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any taxpayer may apply in writing, stating the basis therefor, to the Director for a revision of the tax assessed against him.
Any request for a revision must be made within 15 days of the date on which the Director notifies the taxpayer of tax due pursuant to this subtitle.
If no application for revision is made within the 15 day period, the assessment is final. No application for revision shall be considered by the Director unless made within that period.

para.heading: Director to act promptly.
para.text: The Director:
shall act upon such application promptly; and
shall provide notice to the taxpayer of the action.

section.heading: Appeal of decision on refund or revision.

para.text: Within 15 days of notice of action by the Director on the taxpayer's application for revision or refund of an assessment, the taxpayer may request a formal hearing before the Director.
The Director shall grant a hearing and shall give the taxpayer reasonable notice of the time, date, and place of the hearing.

para.heading: Conduct of hearing.
para.text: The Director shall have the power:
to administer oaths; and
to prescribe all necessary and reasonable rules for the conduct of a hearing.
After a hearing, the Director:
shall make a determination concerning any revision of the assessment, or grant or refuse a refund; and
shall provide notice to the taxpayer of this determination.
In addition, the Director may levy a deficiency assessment against the taxpayer for any additional taxes found to be due.

A taxpayer dissatisfied with the Director's final determination may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.
A party to the judicial review may appeal the court's final judgment to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

The testimony or evidence of any person compelled to testify in a tax proceeding under this subtitle shall not be used against that person in any criminal proceeding, except for perjury in the tax proceeding.
The Director shall not release the compelled testimony of any person to any law enforcement agency for direct or derivative use, except for perjury.

However, if by independent evidence a law enforcement agency makes a criminal case against a compelled witness using evidence independent of and not derived from the compelled testimony, such law enforcement agency shall be free to proceed with the case.

It shall be unlawful for the Director or any other public official or employee to divulge or otherwise make known in any manner any particular set forth or disclosed in any report or return required by this subtitle or records used to determine the amount of assessment except in connection with a proceeding involving taxes due under this subtitle or any state or federal law.

However, any records, receipts, or other information seized by any law enforcement officer or taxation official in any investigation may be returned to the seizing law enforcement or taxation agency upon request for said return.

para.heading: Publication of statistics.
para.text: Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the publication of statistics so classified as to prevent the identity of particular reports or returns and the items thereof.

section.heading: Liability not abated by death.
section.text: Taxes, penalties, and interest assessed under this subtitle shall not abate by death of taxpayer.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director may promulgate such rules, regulations, and procedures as are necessary or appropriate to administer this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

section.heading: Judicial assistance.
section.text: The Director may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for an order compelling such testimony, records, or evidence under proper safeguards as the court may deem necessary or appropriate to carry out the provisions of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Whenever it is ascertained by the Director or the City Solicitor that a lesser sum may be collected than the total taxes, penalties, and interest due, the City Solicitor shall be authorized to:
compromise the claim;
accept the lesser sum on behalf of the Director; and
issue a release of the claim or satisfaction of the judgment as though the same had been paid in full.

para.heading: Limitation.
para.text: Such compromise is authorized only in such cases where the City Solicitor and the Director concur that the full amount would be uncollectible.
In general.
Evasion of payment or the willful refusal on the part of any person to pay taxes over to the Director as required by this subtitle shall be a misdemeanor and upon conviction the person is subject:
to imprisonment not exceeding 12 months or to a fine not exceeding $1,000, or both; and
additionally, to a civil penalty of 100% of the amount of the assessment, in addition to the actual assessment provided by this subtitle.

para.heading: Evidence of willful refusal.
para.text: Willful refusal is evidenced by failure to pay the full amount due within 15 days of the date of the assessment.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Advertising host.
para.text: "Advertising host" means a person who:
owns or controls a billboard, posterboard, or other sign; and
charges fees for its use as an outdoor advertising display.

para.heading: Finance Director; Director.
para.text: "Finance Director" or "Director" means the Director of Finance or a designee of the Director of Finance.

para.heading: Outdoor advertising display.
para.text: "Outdoor advertising display" means an outdoor display of a 10 square foot or larger image or message that directs attention to a business, commodity, service, event, or other activity that is:
sold, offered, or conducted somewhere other than on the premises on which the display is made; and
sold, offered, or conducted on the premises only incidentally if at all.

para.heading: Square foot of advertising imagery.
para.text: "Square foot of advertising imagery" means a square foot of space occupied by an outdoor advertising display.

section.heading: Tax imposed.
section.text: An excise tax is imposed on the privilege of exhibiting outdoor advertising displays in the City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The annual amount of the tax imposed is at the following rates per square foot of advertising imagery:
$15 per square foot of advertising imagery for an electronic outdoor advertising display that changes images more than once a day; and
$5 per square foot of advertising imagery for any other outdoor advertising display.

para.heading: Tax for a single space.
para.text: If a single space is used for multiple outdoor advertising displays during the course of one reporting period, the advertising host who makes that space available:
must pay the annual tax as if the display that would generate the highest tax liability had been in place for the entire year; and
need not pay an additional tax for any other displays in that space.
Each advertising host must file a report with the Finance Director on or before July 10 of each year for the preceding tax year (July 1 through June 30).
The report must:
specify the number of separate spaces made available by the advertising host for the exhibition of outdoor advertising displays;
indicate the location and size of each outdoor advertising display exhibited in the preceding tax year;
be in a form the Director approves; and
contain any additional information required by the Director.

para.heading: Payment due with report.
para.text: The tax imposed by this subtitle is due at the time the report is filed.

annotations.annotation: This subtitle was enacted by Ord. 13-139, effective July 20, 2013. Section 3 of that Ordinance provides that “the first report and a prorated tax payment under [§ 29-5] are due on or before July 10, 2014, for the period beginning on the effective date of this Ordinance through June 30, 2014”.

section.heading: Interest and civil penalties.
section.text: If an advertising host fails to pay the tax imposed by this subtitle when due, the advertising host must pay the Finance Director, in addition to the tax due:

para.text: interest at the rate of 1% for each month or fraction of a month that the tax is overdue; and
a penalty of 10% of the amount of the tax due.

section.heading: Records.
section.text: Every advertising host must:

para.text: keep and maintain complete and accurate records of all of its outdoor advertising displays, as necessary or otherwise required by the Finance Director; and
make these records available, at all times during business hours, for inspection and audit by the Finance Director or other authorized agent, employee, or representative of the City.

para.heading: Director to obtain information.
para.text: If any advertising host fails to make the report, remit the tax due, or keep records as required by this subtitle, the Finance Director may attempt to obtain other available information on which to base an estimate of the tax due.

para.heading: Director to estimate tax.
para.text: As soon as the Director obtains this information, the Director may proceed to determine the tax due and assess that tax, plus interest and penalties, against the advertising host liable for the tax.
The Director may then notify the advertising host by mail, sent to that advertising host's last known address, of the total amount of the tax, interest, and penalties.
The total amount is payable within 10 days from the date of this notice.

section.heading: Sale or closing of business.
section.text: If an advertising host sells or otherwise closes all or part of its operations:

para.text: any tax attributable to the operations sold or closed becomes immediately due and payable; and
within 3 days of the sale or closing, that advertising host must submit the required report and remit the total amount of the tax due.

section.heading: Lien on property.
section.text: The tax, interest, and penalties imposed by this subtitle are a lien on all property, real and personal, of any advertising host liable for their payment.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director may adopt rules and regulations as necessary or appropriate to:

para.text: govern the payment, collection, and accounting of the tax imposed by this subtitle;
define any terms used in connection with the imposition and collection of the tax imposed under this subtitle;
provide for the compromise of disputed claims and, for good and sufficient cause shown, the waiver of interest and penalties;
provide for the refund of any tax, interest, or penalty erroneously or illegally paid; and
otherwise administer, enforce, and carry out this subtitle.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or to imprisonment for not more than 12 months or to both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

container.heading: Property Assessed Clean Energy (PACE) Loan Program

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Administrator.
para.text: "Administrator" means the contractor selected under § 30-3 {"Program administration"} of this subtitle to administer the PACE Loan Program for the City.

para.heading: Clean energy lender.
para.text: "Clean energy lender" means a private lender who provides a clean energy loan to a commercial property owner under this subtitle.

para.heading: Clean energy loan.
para.text: "Clean energy loan" means a non-accelerating loan made under this subtitle by a clean energy lender to the owner of a commercial property.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Commercial property" has the meaning stated in the Enabling Law.

para.heading: Illustrations.
para.text: "Commercial property" includes any industrial, multi-family residential (more than 4 dwelling units), non-profit, institutional, or agricultural property that meets the eligibility requirements of this subtitle.

para.heading: Enabling Law.
para.text: "Enabling Law" means the State's Local Government Article, Title 1, Subtitle 11 {"Clean Energy Loan Programs"}.

para.heading: Energy efficiency project.
para.text: "Energy efficient project" means the installation of new or replacement fixtures, products, devices, equipment, systems, materials, or measures that:
increase a commercial property's energy or water efficiency;
decrease a commercial property's energy or water consumption; or
reduce a commercial property's utility costs.

para.heading: Energy improvement.
para.text: "Energy improvement" means an energy efficiency project or renewable energy project that qualifies under this subtitle.

para.heading: Finance Director.
para.text: "Finance Director" means the Director of the City Department of Finance or that Director's designee.

para.heading: Financing agreement.
para.text: "Financing agreement" means an agreement between a property owner and a clean energy lender that provides for the terms and conditions of a clean energy loan.

para.heading: PACE Loan Program; Program.
para.text: "PACE Loan Program" or "Program" means the Property Assessed Clean Energy Loan Program established under this subtitle.

para.heading: Property owner.
para.text: "Property owner" means the owner of a new or existing commercial property located in the City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Renewable energy project" means the installation of new or replacement renewable energy technologies, devices, or systems that generate electric or thermal energy with a nameplate capacity authorized by the Enabling Law.

para.heading: Illustrations.
para.text: "Renewable energy projects" includes projects that generate thermal or electrical energy by using natural resources such as solar, wind, biomass, landfill gas, municipal solid waste, marine or hydrokinetic, or geothermal resources.

para.heading: Surcharge.
para.text: "Surcharge" means the repayment obligation of a clean energy loan, including principal, interest, and administrative costs, collected from a property owner through the City's property tax billing system.

section.heading: PACE Program established.
section.text: As authorized by the Enabling Law, there is a Property Assessed Clean Energy Loan Program for Baltimore City.

para.heading: Nature of City's role.
para.text: The Mayor and City Council of Baltimore:
serves only as a PACE Loan Program sponsor, facilitating the repayment of clean energy loan obligations through the City's property tax billing system; and
is not at any time liable for any clean energy loan obligation authorized by this subtitle.

para.heading: Selection of Administrator.
para.text: Subject to the approval of the Board of Estimates and to any applicable requirements imposed by or adopted under City Charter Article VI, § 11 {"Procurement"}, the Finance Director, in consultation with the Baltimore City Office of Sustainability, shall contract for a Program Administrator, either:
by expanding the scope of an existing municipal contract vehicle;
through a competitive procurement process;
by using an existing Administrator contracted through a cooperative purchasing agreement of the Washington Metropolitan Council of Governments; or
by entering into an agreement with a private entity to administer the PACE Loan Program.

The administrative costs of the PACE Loan Program shall be borne by the property owners participating in the program, and the share of administrative costs applicable to an individual clean energy loan shall be included in the loan's financing agreement.
These administrative costs may not exceed the actual expenses incurred by the City to administer the program.

para.heading: Fees.
para.text: The City may charge property owners who participate in the PACE Loan Program the following, non-financeable fees:
a reasonable application fee; and
recording fees associated with participation in the Program.

para.heading: Adoption.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Finance Director, in consultation with the Program Administrator and the Baltimore City Office of Sustainability, shall adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: These rules and regulations shall:
clearly delineate the respective roles and responsibilities of property owners, clean energy lenders, the Program Administrator, and the Finance Director; and
include:
methodologies for determining the eligibility of commercial properties, property owners, and energy improvements;
minimum underwriting standards for clean energy lenders;

the documentation required on the Administrator's request to demonstrate that the energy savings generated by an energy efficiency project exceed a property owner's obligations under a clean energy loan financing agreement;
efficient application intake, processing, and transaction closing procedures;
terms and provisions to be included in a Notice of Surcharge Levy to be recorded by the clean energy lender or the Program Administrator in the Land Records of Baltimore City;
required data management services that conform to City practices;
Program outreach strategies; and
annual program participation and performance reporting requirements.
